Nipper
Audit Report
Friday, September 30, 2022
 

Summary

Nipper performed an audit on Friday, September 30, 2022 of the network device described in the audit scope. The report consists of the following:

  • a best practice security audit section which details any identified security-related issues. Each security issue identified includes details of what was found together with the impact of the issue, how easy it would be for an attacker to exploit and a recommendation. The recommendations may include alternatives and, where relevant, the commands to resolve the issue;
  • a Defence Information Systems Agency (DISA) Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG) report section that provides compliance information against specific STIG benchmarks. The report includes a summary of the findings, detailed findings and recommendations on remedial action together with references and severity information.

S.1 Audit Scope

The scope of this audit was limited to the device described in Table 1.

Table 1: Audit scope
Device Name OS
Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA ASA 9.1(1)

S.2 Security Audit

Nipper performed a best practice security audit of the one device detailed in the scope and identified 42 security-related findings. Although significant findings were identified they did not comprise the most significant percentage of the findings identified by Nipper. Each of the findings identified is described in greater detail in the main body of this report.

Nipper identified a number of clear-text protocol related findings. It is important that all clear-text protocol services should be replaced with cryptographically secure alternatives in order to help prevent unauthorized eavesdropping of potentially sensitive data. Furthermore, the clear-text services are often used for administration purposes and a malicious user, or attacker, who is able to monitor the communications may also gain access to authentication credentials that could then lead them to gain administrative access to the system.

Nipper can draw the following statistics from the results of this security assessment (percentages have been rounded). 4 findings (10%) were rated as critical, 9 findings (21%) were rated as high, 10 findings (24%) were rated as medium, 13 findings (31%) were rated as low and 6 findings (14%) were rated as informational.

Severity Classification
[No canvas support]
Issue Classification
[No canvas support]

Table 2 details the number of findings identified for each audited device and the rating of the highest rated finding.

Table 2: Summary of findings for each device
Device Name Findings Highest Rating
Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA 42 Critical
Table 3: Nipper "Impact" to CVSS v2 "Confidentiality"
Informational Low Medium High Critical
Complete 0 0 1 3 2
Partial 1 5 7 7 6
None 4 2 4 0 0

1

Your Report

This report was produced by Nipper on Friday, September 30, 2022. The body of this report contains the following reports:

  • Best Practice Security;
  • DISA STIG Compliance;
  • Appendix.

During this report various text styles, icons, ratings and so on are used to describe and reflect various aspects of the analysis and configuration. This section describes those conventions, ratings and icons etc.

1.1 Report Conventions

This report will make use of the text conventions described in Table 6.

Table 6: Report conventions
Convention Description
command This text style represents a device command that should be entered literally.
<user data> This style of text represents a part of a device command that you should substitute with a relevant value. For example, a command that sets a device's IP address would use this text style in a position where the address should be entered.
[optional] These are used to enclose a part of a command that should be treated as optional.
{required} These are used to enclose a part of a command that is required.
| This is used to divide options which could be enclosed in either required or optional braces.

1.2 Compliance Status

Each compliance audit check is given a status that indicates the outcome of the analysis for that audit check. Table 7 describes each possible status.

Table 7: Compliance Status
Status Description
The check has passed all of its required elements. For example, if the check states that the Telnet service should be disabled and it was, then it will be marked as passed.
The check has failed to meet some or all of the requirements. For example, the check may specify that support for only SSH protocol version 2 must be configured and version 1 was found to be configured. Therefore the result would be marked as a fail.
The check requires further investigation in order to determine if it is a pass or fail. For example, if the test states that port security should be enabled on a network switch port or it needs to be physically secured. If the devices configuration does not show that the network port has port security enabled, then an investigation of the physical security would have to be performed in order to determine this checks status. Therefore this check would be reported as needing further investigation.

1.3 DISA STIG Ratings

Severity Category Codes (referred to as CAT) are a measure of vulnerabilities used to assess a facility or system security posture. The DISA STIG category codes are specified against each guidance check based on guidelines outlined in Table 8.

Table 8: STIG Vulnerability Severity Category Code Definitions
Rating DISA Category Code Guidelines
CAT I Any vulnerability, the exploitation of which will directly and immediately result in loss of Confidentiality, Availability, or Integrity.
CAT II Any vulnerability, the exploitation of which has a potential to result in loss of Confidentiality, Availability, or Integrity.
CAT III Any vulnerability, the existence of which degrades measures to protect against loss of Confidentiality, Availability, or Integrity.

1.4 Nipper Ratings

Each finding identified and scored using the Nipper rating system is rated against both the impact of the finding and how easy it would be for an attacker to exploit. The fix rating provides a guide to the effort required to resolve the finding. The overall rating for the finding is calculated based on the finding's impact and ease ratings.

1.4.1 Impact Rating

A finding's impact rating is determined using the criteria outlined in Table 9.

Table 9: The impact rating
Rating Description
Critical These findings can pose a very significant security risk. The findings that have a critical impact are typically those that would allow an attacker to gain full administrative access to the device. For a firewall device, allowing all traffic to pass through the device unfiltered would receive this rating as filtering traffic to protect other devices is the primary purpose of a firewall.
High These findings pose a significant risk to security, but have some limitations on the extent to which they can be abused. User level access to a device and a DoS vulnerability in a critical service would fall into this category. A firewall device that allowed significant unfiltered access, such as allowing entire subnets through or not filtering in all directions, would fall into this category. A router that allows significant modification of its routing configuration would also fall into this category.
Medium These findings have significant limitations on the direct impact they can cause. Typically, these findings would include significant information leakage findings, less significant DoS findings or those that provide significantly limited access. An SNMP service that is secured with a default or a dictionary-based community string would typically fall into this rating, as would a firewall that allows unfiltered access to a range of services on a device.
Low These findings represent a low level security risk. A typical finding would involve information leakage that could be useful to an attacker, such as a list of users or version details. A non-firewall device that was configured with weak network filtering would fall into this category.
Informational These findings represent a very low level of security risk. These findings include minor information leakage, unnecessary services or legacy protocols that present no real risk to security.

1.4.2 Ease Rating

A finding's ease rating is determined using the criteria outlined in Table 10.

Table 10: The ease rating
Rating Description
Trivial The finding requires little-to-no knowledge on behalf of an attacker and can be exploited using standard operating system tools. A firewall device which had a network filtering configuration that enables traffic to pass through would fall into this category.
Easy The finding requires some knowledge for an attacker to exploit, which could be performed using standard operating system tools or tools downloaded from the Internet. An administrative service without or with a default password would fall into this category, as would a simple software vulnerability exploit.
Moderate The finding requires specific knowledge on behalf of an attacker. The finding could be exploited using a combination of operating system tools or publicly available tools downloaded from the Internet.
Challenging A security finding that falls into this category would require significant effort and knowledge on behalf of the attacker. The attacker may require specific physical access to resources or to the network infrastructure in order to successfully exploit the vulnerability. Furthermore, a combination of attacks may be required.

1.4.3 Fix Rating

A finding's fix rating is determined using the criteria outlined in Table 11.

Table 11: The fix rating
Rating Description
Involved The resolution of the finding will require significant resources to resolve and is likely to include disruption to network services, and possibly the modification of other network device configurations. The finding could involve upgrading a device's OS and possible modifications to the hardware.
Planned The finding resolution involves planning, testing and could cause some disruption to services. This finding could involve changes to routing protocols and changes to network filtering.
Quick The finding is quick to resolve. Typically this would just involve changing a small number of settings and would have little-to-no effect on network services.

1.4.4 Notes

It is worth noting that Nipper is unable to provide an accurate risk assessment due to a lack of contextual information. For example, in the case where highly sensitive information is processed, a Denial of Service (DoS) vulnerability poses less of a risk than the integrity of the data or an attacker gaining access to it. Similarly, for a situation where up-time is critical, a DoS vulnerability could be more important than the leakage of sensitive information. Therefore the ratings provided by Nipper are only intended to be a guide to an finding's significance.

1.5 Network Filtering Actions

This report includes a number of network filter rules. Table 12 describes the filter rule actions used within the report.

Table 12: Network filtering actions
Action Description
Allow the network traffic, enabling it to pass through to its destination.
Drop the network traffic, preventing it from reaching its destination and not informing the sender that it has been dropped.

1.6 Network Filter Objects

This report details the type of network objects used within the filter rules. Table 13 describes the object types used within the report.

Table 13: Network filtering actions
Object Description
This represents anything and everything. Any address, user, application etc.
Describes a single IPv4 or IPv6 address.
Specific IPv4 or IPv6 network address.
A network interface, such as eth0 or fastEthernet0/1.

2

Best Practice Security

Notes

beans

2.1 Introduction

Nipper performed a best practice security audit on Friday, September 30, 2022 of the device detailed in Table 14.

Table 14: Best practice security audit device list
Device Name OS
Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA ASA 9.1(1)

2.1.1 Security Issue Findings

Each security issue identified by Nipper is described with a finding, the impact of the issue, how easy it would be for an attacker to exploit the issue and a recommendation.

2.1.1.1 Issue Finding

The issue finding describes what Nipper identified during the best practice security audit. Typically, the finding will include background information on what particular configuration settings are prior to describing what was found.

2.1.1.2 Issue Impact

The issue impact describes what an attacker could achieve from exploiting the finding. However, it is worth noting that the impact of an issue can often be influenced by other configuration settings, which could heighten or partially mitigate the issue. For example, a weak password could be partially mitigated if the access gained from using it is restricted in some way.

2.1.1.3 Issue Ease

The issue ease describes the knowledge, skill, level of access and time scales that would be required by an attacker in order to exploit an issue. The issue ease will describe, where relevant, if any Open Source or commercially available tools could be used to exploit an issue.

2.1.1.4 Issue Recommendation

Each issue includes a recommendation section which describes the steps that Nipper recommends should be taken in order to mitigate the issue. The recommendation includes, where relevant, the commands that can be used to resolve the issue.

2.2 Rules Allow Access To Blacklist Host and Service

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Critical
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.2.1 Finding

The Host and Service Black List specifies traffic that should not be allowed through the network device. Entries in this black list might typically be internal resources containing highly sensitive or confidential information or external resources that may pose a threat to the network.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following blacklist host services:

  • Service http on host 212.241.243.218.

2.2.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "103" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rule 1.

The filter list "103" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 15: extended ACL: 103
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port a_Office_port to port 80 N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "my_accesslist" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rule 1.

The filter list "my_accesslist" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 16: extended ACL: my_accesslist
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 my-DNS from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "officeACL3" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rule 1.

The filter list "officeACL3" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 17: extended ACL: officeACL3
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 officeService1 from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "Office-access" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rule 1.

The filter list "Office-access" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 18: extended ACL: Office-access
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

2.2.2 Impact

Violating the Host and Service Black List could provide an attacker with a range of vulnerabilities to exploit. If the blacklisted resource is internal and sensitive, an attacker may have access to confidential and private information. If it is an external resource, an attacker may be able to introduce some other vulnerabilities into the network.

2.2.3 Ease

Access to the hosts and services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

2.2.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that firewall Access control lists are configured in a manner that does not violate specified Host and Service Black Lists.

2.2.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

Access Control Entry (ACE) can be deleted from an Access Control List (ACL) using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.2.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0008
  • Classification: Filtering

2.3 Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Critical
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.3.1 Finding

Access to restricted network user and administration services are typically secured using username and password authentication credentials. The strength of the authentication credentials is even more important if the service allows for devices to be reconfigured or it allows access to potentially sensitive information.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if any enabled user accounts had a dictionary-based authentication password.

2.3.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

The following table contains user accounts configured with a dictionary-based password on Office-Cisco-ASA and includes administrative access to the device.

Table 19: Users on Office-Cisco-ASA with a dictionary-based password
User Password Strength
enable password Dictionary-based

2.3.2 Impact

A malicious user, or remote attacker, who is able to connect to an administrative service will be able to perform a dictionary-based attack in order to identify valid authentication credentials and logon to the device. The attacker will then be able to perform administrative and user level tasks. This could include re-configuring the device, extracting potentially sensitive information and disabling the device. Once an attacker has obtained the configuration from the device they may be able to identify authentication credentials that could then be used to gain access to other network devices.

2.3.3 Ease

Dictionary-based password guessing attacks have been widely documented on the Internet and published media, enabling an attacker with very little knowledge or experience to perform the attack. There are a number of different dictionary-based password guessing tools and password dictionaries available on the Internet. Additionally an experienced attacker is likely to have a collection of personal password dictionaries which they have built up over time. However, there are a number of factors that may discourage an attacker from performing a dictionary-based attack.

  1. Account lockout facilities can quickly prevent access to the account.
  2. Device protection mechanisms may slow or disconnect connections where multiple authentication attempts are made in a short period of time.
  3. Brute-forcing can be very time consuming, especially if the password is long or made up of various character types.
  4. Network administrators may be alerted to locked out accounts or authentication attempts.

2.3.4 Recommendation

Nipper strongly recommends that all user accounts should have strong passwords. If the user accounts are not being used then Nipper recommends that they should be either removed or disabled.

Nipper recommends that:

  • user passwords should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the user password should not be repeated more than three times;
  • user passwords should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • user passwords should include numbers;
  • user passwords should include punctuation characters;
  • user passwords should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • user passwords should not be based on dictionary words.

2.3.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

The following commands can be used on Cisco ASA devices to configure the initial password, enable password and a user account with a password:

password <password>
enable password <password>
username <name> password <password>

2.3.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ATH-0005
  • Classification: Authentication

The following findings are related to this one:

  • User Account Names Contained "admin" (see section 2.21).

2.4 Filter Rules Allow From Any Source Address

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Critical
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.4.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow from any address.

2.4.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "101" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed from any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 20: extended ACL: 101
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 ftp_servers Any IP any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "103" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed from any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 21: extended ACL: 103
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port a_Office_port to port 80 N/A

2.4.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.4.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.4.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.4.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.4.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0018
  • Classification: Filtering

2.5 Filter Rules Allow To Any Destination Address

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Critical
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.5.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to any address.

2.5.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "103" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 22: extended ACL: 103
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port a_Office_port to port 80 N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "listy" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 23: conduit ACL: listy
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.50

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "my_accesslist" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 24: extended ACL: my_accesslist
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 my-DNS from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "officeACL3" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 25: extended ACL: officeACL3
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 officeService1 from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "Office-access" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 26: extended ACL: Office-access
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

2.5.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.5.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.5.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.5.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.5.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0021
  • Classification: Filtering

2.6 Rules Allow Access To Administrative Services

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.6.1 Finding

Administrative network services are essential to enable network administrators to remotely configure, update, modify and monitor the systems. Typically these services fall in to two groups:

  • remote command, graphical or web-based environments that enable administrators to quickly configure and manage devices;
  • informational services which either provide alerts, notifications and may also enable the modification of settings using specialist software.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following administrative services:

  • ssh (tcp/22);
  • telnet (tcp/23);
  • tacacs (tcp/49);
  • snmp (udp/161);
  • snmptrap (udp/162);
  • syslog (udp/514).

2.6.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "2" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the administrative services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those administrative services by default if no matching filter rule is found. ssh (TCP port 22), telnet (TCP port 23), tacacs (TCP port 49), snmp (UDP port 161), snmptrap (UDP port 162) and syslog (UDP port 514) were the administrative services not specifically denied.

The filter list "2" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 27: conduit ACL: 2
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.42

Nipper determined that filter list "extended" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the administrative services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those administrative services by default if no matching filter rule is found. ssh (TCP port 22), telnet (TCP port 23), tacacs (TCP port 49), snmp (UDP port 161), snmptrap (UDP port 162) and syslog (UDP port 514) were the administrative services not specifically denied.

The filter list "extended" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 28: extended ACL: extended
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 80 N/A
2 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 21 N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "LOGtest" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmptrap (UDP port 162) was allowed in rule 1.

The filter list "LOGtest" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 29: extended ACL: LOGtest
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeOUTSIDE OfficeVLAN1 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "GR" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmptrap (UDP port 162) was allowed in rule 1.

The filter list "GR" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 30: extended ACL: GR
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes officeFTPserver 192.168.0.0/16 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "101" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmptrap (UDP port 162) was allowed in rule 1.

Table 31: extended ACL: 101
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 ftp_servers Any IP any port N/A
2 Yes 74.165.236.76 68.156.91.20 TCP from any port to port 23032 N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "103" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the administrative services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those administrative services by default if no matching filter rule is found. ssh (TCP port 22), telnet (TCP port 23), tacacs (TCP port 49), snmp (UDP port 161), snmptrap (UDP port 162) and syslog (UDP port 514) were the administrative services not specifically denied.

The filter list "103" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 32: extended ACL: 103
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port a_Office_port to port 80 N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "officeACL1" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmptrap (UDP port 162) was allowed in rule 1.

Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Office_admins pad_network_.- protoGROUP any port N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "officeACL2" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the administrative services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those administrative services by default if no matching filter rule is found. ssh (TCP port 22), telnet (TCP port 23), tacacs (TCP port 49), snmp (UDP port 161), snmptrap (UDP port 162) and syslog (UDP port 514) were the administrative services not specifically denied.

Nipper determined that filter list "3" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the administrative services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those administrative services by default if no matching filter rule is found. ssh (TCP port 22), telnet (TCP port 23), tacacs (TCP port 49), snmp (UDP port 161), snmptrap (UDP port 162) and syslog (UDP port 514) were the administrative services not specifically denied.

  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;

  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;

  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 1;

  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rule 1;

Nipper determined that filter list "Office-access" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;

Table 39: extended ACL: Office-access
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

2.6.2 Impact

The administrative services by their nature enable the remote configuration of a device and access to a wealth of sensitive configuration information. These services are likely to be a prime target for an attacker who may attempt to gain access by exploiting a vulnerability or attacking the authentication systems.

2.6.3 Ease

Access to the administrative network services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

2.6.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that network filter rules should only be configured to allow access to administrative network services from those who are authorized.

2.6.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.6.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0004
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering

2.7 Filter Rules Allow To Any Port

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.7.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to any port.

2.7.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "LOGtest" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 40: extended ACL: LOGtest
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeOUTSIDE OfficeVLAN1 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "GR" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 41: extended ACL: GR
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes officeFTPserver 192.168.0.0/16 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "101" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 42: extended ACL: 101
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 ftp_servers Any IP any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "officeACL1" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 43: extended ACL: officeACL1
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Office_admins pad_network_.- protoGROUP any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "listy" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 44: conduit ACL: listy
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.50

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "my_accesslist" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 45: extended ACL: my_accesslist
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 my-DNS from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "officeACL3" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 46: extended ACL: officeACL3
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 officeService1 from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "Office-access" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 47: extended ACL: Office-access
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

2.7.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.7.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.7.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.7.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.7.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0024
  • Classification: Filtering

2.8 No Console Connection Timeout

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.8.1 Finding

The console connection timeout setting is used to determine if a console connection is no longer being used, enabling a device to determine when a connection can be automatically disconnected. A console connection could become unused if an administrator has not properly terminated a connection and remains authenticated or if they leave their computer unattended without terminating their console session.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the console session timeout was set to 0 seconds.

2.8.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that there was no console session timeout set on Office-Cisco-ASA.

2.8.2 Impact

If an attacker was able to access a system using an authenticated session that is no longer being used, the attacker would be able to perform information gathering, configuration and other malicious activities under the context of the previous authenticated user. Due to the nature of the access, this could be an administrative level of access.

2.8.3 Ease

To exploit this issue an attacker would have to identify a console session that had not been correctly terminated and then take over that session. This could be as simple as plugging a console cable in to a port on the device or taking over a computer system whilst the operator has left their system open, both of which would require physical access. However, an attacker may also be able to perform this attack remotely if an insecure network protocol has been used to remotely gain console access.

2.8.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a timeout period of 10 minutes should be configured for the console connection.

2.8.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

The console timeout can be configured with the following command:

console timeout <timeout-minutes>

2.8.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0003
  • Classification: Administration

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled (see section 2.9);
  • Long SSH Session Timeout (see section 2.10);
  • SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported (see section 2.15);
  • Weak Telnet Service Network Access Restrictions (see section 2.25);
  • Weak SSH Service Network Access Restrictions (see section 2.26).

2.9 Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.9.1 Finding

The Telnet protocol (described in RFC 15 and RFC 854) is a clear-text protocol that is widely used to provide command-based access to systems and applications. Telnet is a simple protocol that was one of the first TCP/IP protocols to be developed, before security features were given a greater importance. Many modern network devices still provide a Telnet service for remote administrative purposes alongside the more secure Secure Shell (SSH) service.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the Telnet service had been disabled.

2.9.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that the Telnet service was enabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

2.9.2 Impact

Due to the lack of encryption provided by the Telnet protocol, an attacker who is able to monitor a Telnet session would be able to view all of the authentication credentials and data passed in the session. The attacker could then attempt to gain access to the device using the authentication credentials extracted from the session and potentially gain access under the context of that user. Since Telnet is commonly used for network device administration this could gain the attacker an administrative level of access.

2.9.3 Ease

To exploit the fact that the Telnet protocol does not provide any encryption, the attacker would need to be able to monitor the Telnet session between a Telnet server and client. In some situations the attacker may not need to perform any further action other than launching a network monitoring tool. However, in a switched network the attacker may need to perform additional actions such as an Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) attack and in a routed environment the attacker may have to compromise the network routing.

Tools that are capable of both monitoring and displaying network traffic in an easy to read form can be downloaded from the Internet. There are also tools that automatically detect where authentication credentials or files are being transferred and display or save the data. Tools are also available that enable an attacker to easily perform a variety of network attacks in order to be able to monitor and intercept sessions between two network devices.

2.9.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the Telnet service should be disabled. If remote administrative access is required then Nipper recommends that a cryptographically secure alternative, such as SSH, should be used instead. If Telnet has to be used then Nipper recommends that network filtering should be employed to restrict access to the service from only those specific devices that need the access.

2.9.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

Telnet access to Cisco ASA devices can be disabled by removing access from all the configured management hosts. This can be done with the following command:

no telnet {<hostname> | <ip-address> <interface>}

2.9.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0036
  • Classification: Administration, Clear-Text
  • RFCs: RFC 15, RFC 854
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telnet

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No Console Connection Timeout (see section 2.8);
  • Weak Telnet Service Network Access Restrictions (see section 2.25).

2.10 Long SSH Session Timeout

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.10.1 Finding

The SSH session timeout setting is used to determine if an SSH session is no longer being used, enabling a device to determine when a connection can be automatically closed. An SSH session could become unused if an administrator has not properly terminated a connection and remains authenticated, such as when terminating an SSH client. The session could also unused if the user leaves their computer unattended without terminating the session.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the SSH service specific idle session timeout was set to 10 minutes or less.

2.10.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that the SSH service idle session timeout configured on Office-Cisco-ASA was set to 50 minutes.

2.10.2 Impact

If an attacker was able to access a system using an authenticated session that is no longer being used, the attacker would be able to perform information gathering, configuration and other malicious activities under the context of the previous authenticated user. Due to the nature of the access, this could be an administrative level of access.

2.10.3 Ease

To exploit this issue an attacker would first have to identify a working SSH session before it expires, possibly prior to it becoming unused by the user, and then be able to control that SSH session. This may be as simple as using the user's computer whilst they are away, otherwise the attacker may have to exploit a weakness in the protocol or perform a man-in-the-middle attack. In the case of exploiting a weakness in the SSH protocol, it is made far more difficult due to the cryptographic nature of the protocol and its session security features.

2.10.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that an SSH session timeout period of TIMEOUT should be configured.

2.10.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

The SSH connection timeout can be configured with the following command:

ssh timeout <timeout-minutes>

2.10.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0032
  • Classification: Administrationg
  • RFCs: RFC 4250, RFC 4251, RFC 4252, RFC 4253, RFC 4254, RFC 4255, RFC 4256
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSH_(Secure_Shell)

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No Console Connection Timeout (see section 2.8);
  • SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported (see section 2.15);
  • Weak SSH Service Network Access Restrictions (see section 2.26).

2.11 Long HTTPS Service Session Idle Timeout

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.11.1 Finding

The HTTPS server session timeout setting is used to determine if a web session is no longer being used, enabling a device to determine when a connection can be automatically disconnected. A HTTPS server session could become unused if an administrator has not properly terminated a connection and remains authenticated, such as when a user does not click on a logout button. The session could also become unused if the user leaves their computer unattended without terminating the session.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the HTTPS specific idle timeout was set to 10 minutes or less.

2.11.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that the HTTPS service specific timeout configured on Office-Cisco-ASA was set to 300 minutes.

2.11.2 Impact

If an attacker was able to access a system using an authenticated session that is no longer being used, the attacker would be able to perform information gathering, configuration and other malicious activities under the context of the previous authenticated user. The level of access could potentially be at an administrative level.

2.11.3 Ease

To exploit this issue an attacker would first have to identify a working HTTPS server session before it expires, possibly prior to it becoming unused by the user, and then be able to control that web session. This may be as simple as using the user's computer whilst they are away, otherwise the attacker may have to exploit a weakness in the protocol or perform a man-in-the-middle attack. The man-in-the-middle attack could be performed using a proxy server, but a user could become suspicious if the session is using HTTPS and the web browser provides the user with a certificate warning.

2.11.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a HTTPS server session idle timeout period of 10 minutes should be configured.

2.11.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0018
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 2616, RFC 2818, RFC 2546
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Transfer_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported (see section 2.20);
  • Weak HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions (see section 2.27).

2.12 Rules Allow Access To Clear-Text Services

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.12.1 Finding

Clear-text protocol services are those network services that provide no encryption of the network traffic between the service and a connected client. Whilst some clear-text protocol services are relatively simple and be of little of interest to an attacker, others may be used for the remote administration of the device and transfer their authentication credentials with no encryption.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following clear-text services:

  • ftp-data (tcp/20);
  • ftp (tcp/21);
  • telnet (tcp/23);
  • smtp (tcp/25);
  • tacacs (tcp/49);
  • tftp (tcp/69);
  • http (tcp/80);
  • rtelnet (tcp/107);
  • pop2 (tcp/109);
  • pop3 (tcp/110);
  • nntp (tcp/119);
  • ldap (tcp/389);
  • exec (tcp/512);
  • login (tcp/513);
  • shell (tcp/514);
  • rsync (tcp/873).

2.12.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "2" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the clear-text services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those clear-text services by default if no matching filter rule is found. ftp-data (TCP port 20), ftp (TCP port 21), telnet (TCP port 23), smtp (TCP port 25), tacacs (TCP port 49), tftp (TCP port 69), http (TCP port 80), rtelnet (TCP port 107), pop2 (TCP port 109), pop3 (TCP port 110), nntp (TCP port 119), ldap (TCP port 389), exec (TCP port 512), login (TCP port 513), shell (TCP port 514) and rsync (TCP port 873) were the clear-text services not specifically denied.

The filter list "2" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 48: conduit ACL: 2
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.42

Nipper determined that filter list "extended" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rule 2.

Nipper determined that filter list "extended" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the clear-text services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those clear-text services by default if no matching filter rule is found. ftp-data (TCP port 20), telnet (TCP port 23), smtp (TCP port 25), tacacs (TCP port 49), tftp (TCP port 69), rtelnet (TCP port 107), pop2 (TCP port 109), pop3 (TCP port 110), nntp (TCP port 119), ldap (TCP port 389), exec (TCP port 512), login (TCP port 513), shell (TCP port 514) and rsync (TCP port 873) were the clear-text services not specifically denied.

The filter list "extended" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 49: extended ACL: extended
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 80 N/A
2 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 21 N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "LOGtest" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rule 1.

The filter list "LOGtest" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 50: extended ACL: LOGtest
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeOUTSIDE OfficeVLAN1 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "GR" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rule 1.

The filter list "GR" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 51: extended ACL: GR
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes officeFTPserver 192.168.0.0/16 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "101" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rule 1.

Nipper determined that filter list "103" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to the clear-text service http (TCP port 80) in filter rule 1.

Nipper determined that filter list "103" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the clear-text services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those clear-text services by default if no matching filter rule is found. ftp-data (TCP port 20), ftp (TCP port 21), telnet (TCP port 23), smtp (TCP port 25), tacacs (TCP port 49), tftp (TCP port 69), rtelnet (TCP port 107), pop2 (TCP port 109), pop3 (TCP port 110), nntp (TCP port 119), ldap (TCP port 389), exec (TCP port 512), login (TCP port 513), shell (TCP port 514) and rsync (TCP port 873) were the clear-text services not specifically denied.

Nipper determined that filter list "Office-access" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rule 1.

The filter list "Office-access" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 60: extended ACL: Office-access
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

2.12.2 Impact

Due to a lack of encryption, an attacker who is able to monitor clear-text protocol service network communications would gain access to the information transmitted. The information could include the authentication credentials used to access the service or any other information transferred. Furthermore, some of the services could be used for remote administration and once accessed could be used to attack other devices on the network, bypassing any configured network filtering. Additionally, clear-text protocol services are vulnerable to man in the middle style attacks.

2.12.3 Ease

Access to the network services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

Network monitoring tools are available on the Internet and, depending on the operating system, may be installed by default. It is worth noting that an attacker may have to perform additional actions in order to be in a position where the network traffic can be monitored. This could mean that an attacker would have to perform a layer-2 attack or exploit a weakness in a routing protocol.

2.12.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, network filter rules should not allow access to clear-text protocol services.

2.12.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.12.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0007
  • Classification: Clear-Text, Filtering

2.13 IPSec Aggressive Mode Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.13.1 Finding

IP Security protocol (IPsec) Virtual Private Network (VPN) can negotiate using either main or aggressive modes. Main mode makes use of three two way exchanges:

  1. the first exchange determines that hashes and algorithms to use.
  2. the second exchange is a Diffie-Hellman (DH) exchange to generate the shared secret.
  3. the third exchange is used to verify the peers using the DH tunnel.

Aggressive mode does not send as many packets to setup a VPN tunnel as main mode. This is achieved by not setting up the initial encrypted connection that is used to protect the peer authentication.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that IPSec aggressive mode was not configured to be used during negotiation.

2.13.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified the following IPSec phase 1 configurations on Office-Cisco-ASA that were configured with aggressive mode:

Table 61: IPSec phase 1 configurations
Priority Auth IKE Version Exchange Encryption Hash PRF Mode Lifetime
65535 PSK 1 DH Group 2 (1024-bit) AES (128-bit) SHA1 SHA1 Aggr 1440 minutes

2.13.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to capture an aggressive mode connection exchange would be able to use the captured data to crack the Pre-Shared Key (PSK). Using the cracked PSK the attacker could then attempt to create their own connection to the VPN.

2.13.3 Ease

There is software available on the Internet that can be used to capture and crack the PSK sent in an aggressive mode connection exchange. However, the attacker would need to be able to monitor the network connection and have some understanding of how an IPsec VPN works.

2.13.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the only main mode is configured for all IPsec VPN connections.

2.13.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-VPN-0001
  • RFCs: RFC 5406
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPsec

The following findings are related to this one:

  • IPSec Configured With Weak Encryption (see section 2.18);
  • IPSec With Weak Authentication Hashing Algorithm (see section 2.42).

2.14 No RIP Authentication

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.14.1 Finding

Routing Information Protocol (RIP) is a routing protocol that allows network devices to dynamically adapt to changes in the network infrastructure. There are three main versions of RIP; version 1, 2 and NG. Version 2 of RIP supports authentication using either clear-text or MD5 authentication methods. This ensures that routing updates were sent from a trusted source.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all RIP routing interfaces were configured to provide authentication.

2.14.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified the following RIP routing configuration, applied to network interfaces, on Office-Cisco-ASA:

Table 62: RIP authentication on interfaces
Interface Active Passive Send Receive Auth Key ID
Ethernet0/0 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/1 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/2 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/3 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/4 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/5 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/6 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/7 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Table 63: RIP authentication on interfaces
Interface Active Passive Send Receive Auth Key ID
Vlan1 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Vlan2 Yes No Default Default None N/A

2.14.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to modify the routing table of a routing device in an attempt to route network traffic through a device that they control. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.14.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that could be used to send malicious RIP routing updates. With no authentication configured, an attacker would not have to determine the authentication key prior to sending malicious RIP route updates.

2.14.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that strong authentication keys should be configured for all RIP routing updates with RIP version 2 MD5 authentication.

Nipper recommends that:

  • RIP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the RIP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • RIP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • RIP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • RIP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • RIP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • RIP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.14.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0036
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 1058, RFC 1388, RFC 1723, RFC 2453, RFC 4822
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routing_Information_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • RIP Version 1 Configured (see section 2.19);
  • No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (see section 2.24).

2.15 SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.15.1 Finding

SSH is typically used as a cryptographically secure alternative to Telnet and other clear-text protocols. In addition to command-based access, SSH services can enable the forwarding of network ports (such as X forwarding) or the transfer of files (such as Secure Copy (SCP) or Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP)).

There are two main versions of the SSH protocol, version 1 and 2. Version 2 was developed to both extend the functionality of the protocol and to enhance security. It is common for SSH servers that support both versions of the protocol to be capable of being configured to support connections from clients using different versions of the protocol in order to maintain backward compatibility.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the SSH service had been configured to only accept connections using version 2 of the protocol.

2.15.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper detemined that the SSH service was configured to support versions 1 and 2 of the protocol on Office-Cisco-ASA.

2.15.2 Impact

Although flaws have been identified with SSH protocol version 2, fundamental flaws exist in protocol version 1. Table 64 details some of the vulnerabilities identified in SSH protocol version 1.

Table 64: Known SSH protocol version 1 vulnerabilities
Description CVE CERT
CBC or CFB vulnerability allowing a remote attacker to insert data (and commands) in to an existing SSH session. CVE-1999-1085 VU#13877
A CRC overflow error could enable remote attackers to write to arbitrary locations in a device's memory. CVE-2001-0144 VU#945216
A client authentication forwarding flaw in the protocol could enable a remote attacker to perform a man in the middle attack.   VU#684820
It is possible for an attacker to modify the last block of an SSH connection that is using the IDEA cipher.   VU#315308

2.15.3 Ease

Although a number of vulnerabilities in SSH protocol version 1 are widely known they can be difficult to exploit and some require very specific configurations to also exist. It is more likely that unless the attacker highly motivated and experienced they will seek an alternative weakness to exploit rather than attempting to exploit vulnerabilities with the SSH protocol.

2.15.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the SSH service should be reconfigured to only support version 2 of the protocol.

2.15.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

Cisco ASA devices can be configured to support only SSH protocol version 2 with the following command:

ssh version 2

2.15.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0033
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 4250, RFC 4251, RFC 4252, RFC 4253, RFC 4254, RFC 4255, RFC 4256
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSH_(Secure_Shell)

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No Console Connection Timeout (see section 2.8);
  • Long SSH Session Timeout (see section 2.10);
  • Weak SSH Service Network Access Restrictions (see section 2.26).

2.16 Rules Allow Access To Potentially Sensitive Services

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.16.1 Finding

Whilst not strictly administrative services, a number of network services can be classified as potentially sensitive due to their nature. These network services could be database services that enable applications to connect to and query data, authentication services or Microsoft Windows file sharing services.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following potentially sensitive services:

  • netbios-ns (tcp/137);
  • netbios-ns (udp/137);
  • netbios-dgm (tcp/138);
  • netbios-dgm (udp/138);
  • netbios-ssn (tcp/139);
  • netbios-ssn (udp/139);
  • microsoft-ds (tcp/445);
  • nessus (tcp/1241);
  • ms-sql-s (tcp/1433);
  • ms-sql-s (udp/1433);
  • ms-sql-m (tcp/1434);
  • ms-sql-m (udp/1434);
  • wins (tcp/1512);
  • radius (tcp/1812);
  • mysql (tcp/3306);
  • tns-server (tcp/3308);
  • http-alt (tcp/8080).

2.16.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "2" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the potentially sensitive services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those potentially sensitive services by default if no matching filter rule is found. netbios-ns (TCP port 137), netbios-ns (UDP port 137), netbios-dgm (TCP port 138), netbios-dgm (UDP port 138), netbios-ssn (TCP port 139), netbios-ssn (UDP port 139), microsoft-ds (TCP port 445), nessus (TCP port 1241), ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433), ms-sql-s (UDP port 1433), ms-sql-m (TCP port 1434), ms-sql-m (UDP port 1434), wins (TCP port 1512), radius (TCP port 1812), mysql (TCP port 3306), tns-server (TCP port 3308) and http-alt (TCP port 8080) were the potentially sensitive services not specifically denied.

The filter list "2" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 65: conduit ACL: 2
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.42

Nipper determined that filter list "extended" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the potentially sensitive services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those potentially sensitive services by default if no matching filter rule is found. netbios-ns (TCP port 137), netbios-ns (UDP port 137), netbios-dgm (TCP port 138), netbios-dgm (UDP port 138), netbios-ssn (TCP port 139), netbios-ssn (UDP port 139), microsoft-ds (TCP port 445), nessus (TCP port 1241), ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433), ms-sql-s (UDP port 1433), ms-sql-m (TCP port 1434), ms-sql-m (UDP port 1434), wins (TCP port 1512), radius (TCP port 1812), mysql (TCP port 3306), tns-server (TCP port 3308) and http-alt (TCP port 8080) were the potentially sensitive services not specifically denied.

The filter list "extended" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 66: extended ACL: extended
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 80 N/A
2 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 21 N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "LOGtest" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to potentially sensitive services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially sensitive service http-alt (TCP port 8080) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (TCP port 139) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service microsoft-ds (TCP port 445) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service tns-server (TCP port 3308) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (UDP port 138) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (TCP port 137) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (TCP port 138) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (UDP port 139) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (UDP port 1434) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (UDP port 1433) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service nessus (TCP port 1241) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service mysql (TCP port 3306) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (TCP port 1434) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service radius (TCP port 1812) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service wins (TCP port 1512) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (UDP port 137) was allowed in rule 1.

The filter list "LOGtest" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 67: extended ACL: LOGtest
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeOUTSIDE OfficeVLAN1 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

  • access to potentially sensitive service http-alt (TCP port 8080) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433) was allowed in rule 1;
