Table 77: extended ACL: Office-access
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

2.16.2 Impact

Although there may be a business requirement for access to be permitted to these services, such as access to Windows file shares, these services also offer a tempting target for an attacker. At worst an attacker may be able to exploit configuration or software vulnerabilities in these services in order to gain access to the service host and data. It is also typical for these services to provide an attacker with a wealth of information about the systems, such as enumerating users from a Windows hosts or obtaining software version details from database services.

2.16.3 Ease

Access to the potentially sensitive network services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

2.16.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that access to potentially sensitive services should be restricted to only those who are authorized.

2.16.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.16.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0005
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering

2.17 Rules Allow Access To Potentially Unnecessary Services

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.17.1 Finding

A number of different network services provide little to no functionality and are installed by default on some operating systems. Examples of these services are:

  • echo - a network service that responds with a copy of the data sent to it;
  • qotd - a network service that responds a random quote;
  • discard - a network service that simply ignores anything that is sent to it;
  • chargen - a network service that returns with a repeating character sequence;
  • daytime - a network service that returns the current system time and date.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following potentially unnecessary services:

  • echo (tcp/7);
  • echo (udp/7);
  • discard (tcp/9);
  • discard (udp/9);
  • daytime (tcp/13);
  • daytime (udp/13);
  • qotd (tcp/17);
  • qotd (udp/17);
  • chargen (tcp/19);
  • chargen (udp/19);
  • whoispp (tcp/63);
  • whoispp (udp/63);
  • gopher (tcp/70);
  • finger (tcp/79);
  • finger (udp/79).

2.17.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "2" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the potentially unnecessary services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those potentially unnecessary services by default if no matching filter rule is found. echo (TCP port 7), echo (UDP port 7), discard (TCP port 9), discard (UDP port 9), daytime (TCP port 13), daytime (UDP port 13), qotd (TCP port 17), qotd (UDP port 17), chargen (TCP port 19), chargen (UDP port 19), whoispp (TCP port 63), whoispp (UDP port 63), gopher (TCP port 70), finger (TCP port 79) and finger (UDP port 79) were the potentially unnecessary services not specifically denied.

The filter list "2" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 78: conduit ACL: 2
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.42

Nipper determined that filter list "extended" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the potentially unnecessary services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those potentially unnecessary services by default if no matching filter rule is found. echo (TCP port 7), echo (UDP port 7), discard (TCP port 9), discard (UDP port 9), daytime (TCP port 13), daytime (UDP port 13), qotd (TCP port 17), qotd (UDP port 17), chargen (TCP port 19), chargen (UDP port 19), whoispp (TCP port 63), whoispp (UDP port 63), gopher (TCP port 70), finger (TCP port 79) and finger (UDP port 79) were the potentially unnecessary services not specifically denied.

The filter list "extended" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 79: extended ACL: extended
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 80 N/A
2 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 21 N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "LOGtest" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (UDP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (UDP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (UDP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (UDP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (UDP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (UDP port 19) was allowed in rule 1.

1 Yes Office_admins pad_network_.- protoGROUP any port N/A

Nipper determined that filter list "officeACL2" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the potentially unnecessary services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those potentially unnecessary services by default if no matching filter rule is found. echo (TCP port 7), echo (UDP port 7), discard (TCP port 9), discard (UDP port 9), daytime (TCP port 13), daytime (UDP port 13), qotd (TCP port 17), qotd (UDP port 17), chargen (TCP port 19), chargen (UDP port 19), whoispp (TCP port 63), whoispp (UDP port 63), gopher (TCP port 70), finger (TCP port 79) and finger (UDP port 79) were the potentially unnecessary services not specifically denied.

The filter list "officeACL2" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 85: extended ACL: officeACL2
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 10.100.1.1 10.100.1.2 GRE Level 6

Nipper determined that filter list "3" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not deny access to all the potentially unnecessary services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that Office-Cisco-ASA would automatically deny access to those potentially unnecessary services by default if no matching filter rule is found. echo (TCP port 7), echo (UDP port 7), discard (TCP port 9), discard (UDP port 9), daytime (TCP port 13), daytime (UDP port 13), qotd (TCP port 17), qotd (UDP port 17), chargen (TCP port 19), chargen (UDP port 19), whoispp (TCP port 63), whoispp (UDP port 63), gopher (TCP port 70), finger (TCP port 79) and finger (UDP port 79) were the potentially unnecessary services not specifically denied.

The filter list "3" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 86: extended ACL: 3
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeVLAN1 177.50.1.1 GRE Level 6

Nipper determined that filter list "listy" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (UDP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (UDP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (UDP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (UDP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (UDP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (UDP port 19) was allowed in rule 1.

1 192.168.14.50

Nipper determined that filter list "my_accesslist" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (UDP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (UDP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (UDP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (UDP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (UDP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (UDP port 19) was allowed in rule 1.

Nipper determined that filter list "officeACL3" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rule 1;

Nipper determined that filter list "Office-access" on Office-Cisco-ASA allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (UDP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (UDP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (UDP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (UDP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (UDP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (UDP port 19) was allowed in rule 1.

The filter list "Office-access" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA is described in the following table.

Table 90: extended ACL: Office-access
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

2.17.2 Impact

Although a number of these services may appear to be relatively harmless, serious issues may exist with their use and running unnecessary services also places a burden on the host system. Furthermore, an attacker may be able to use a combination of some network services such as chargen and echo to perform a DoS attack.

2.17.3 Ease

Access to the potentially unnecessary network services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

2.17.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, network filter rules should be configured to prevent access to potentially unnecessary services. Additionally, if the potentially unnecessary network services are not required, Nipper suggests that they should be disabled.

2.17.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.17.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0006
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering

2.18 IPSec Configured With Weak Encryption

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.18.1 Finding

IPsec peers negotiate connections using a number of different protocols, authentication hashing and encryption standards. The encryption algorithm is used to protect the data being transferred from being reviewed by someone who is able to monitor the connection.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all IPSec configurations were configured to use only Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 140-2 validated encryption.

2.18.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified the following IPSec phase-1 configuration on Office-Cisco-ASA with non-FIPS 140-2 validated encryption:

Table 91: Phase-1 with non-FIPS 140-2 validated encryption
Priority Auth IKE Version Exchange Encryption Hash PRF Mode Lifetime
40 PSK 2 DH Group 5 (1536-bit)
DH Group 2 (1024-bit)		 DES (56-bit) SHA1 SHA1 Main 1440 minutes

Nipper identified the following IPSec Transformation Set configuration on Office-Cisco-ASA with non-FIPS 140-2 validated encryption:

Table 92: Transformation set with non-FIPS 140-2 validated encryption
Name Encryption Hash Mode
ESP-DES-SHA DES (56-bit) SHA1 Tunnel
ESP-DES-MD5 DES (56-bit) MD5 Tunnel
ESP-DES-SHA-TRANS DES (56-bit) SHA1 Transport
ESP-DES-MD5-TRANS DES (56-bit) MD5 Transport
DES DES (56-bit) SHA1
MD5		 Tunnel

2.18.2 Impact

With weak encryption ciphers configured on a VPN connection an attacker, who is able to monitor the connection, could be able to break the encryption offline in order to gain access to the transmitted data.

2.18.3 Ease

Breaking even the weakest of encryption algorithms will require both skill and time on behalf of the attacker. The attacker would also need to be in a position where they can monitor and capture network packets sent between the VPN peers. However, the attacker could make use of freely available code in order to assist with the breaking of the encryption.

2.18.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a strong encryption algorithm should be configured for all IPsec VPN connections. Nipper suggests that FIPS validated encryption algorithms should be selected for the VPN encryption.

2.18.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-VPN-0006
  • RFCs: RFC 5406
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPsec

The following findings are related to this one:

  • IPSec Aggressive Mode Enabled (see section 2.13);
  • IPSec With Weak Authentication Hashing Algorithm (see section 2.42).

2.19 RIP Version 1 Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.19.1 Finding

RIP is a routing protocol that allows network devices to dynamically adapt to changes in the network infrastructure. There are three main versions of RIP:

  • version 1 of the protocol, outlined in RFC 1058, supports simple routing updates with support only for classful routing and broadcast updates;
  • version 2 of the protocol, outlined in RFC 2453, added support for CIDR, authentication (both in clear-text and MD5 forms) and multicast updates;
  • NG, outlined in RFC 2080, adds support for Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6) but does not include support for authentication.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that sending or receiving RIP version 1 was not configured.

2.19.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that sending or receiving RIP version 1 was configured on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Table 93: RIP configurations allowing version 1
Router Enabled Send Version Receive Version Update Interval
  Enabled 1 1 0
Table 94: RIP network interface configurations allowing version 1
Interface Active Passive Send Receive Auth Key ID
Ethernet0/0 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/1 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/2 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/3 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/4 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/5 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/6 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Ethernet0/7 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Vlan1 Yes No Default Default None N/A
Vlan2 Yes No Default Default None N/A

2.19.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to modify the routing table of a routing device in an attempt to route network traffic through a device that they control. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

Another issue with RIP version 1, though not necessarily a security one, is that broadcast updates can wake up computers that are shutdown on the Local Area Network (LAN).

2.19.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can be used to send malicious RIP routing updates. With RIP version 1 supported, the attacker would not need to provide authentication information.

2.19.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if RIP is required, only support for version 2 should be configured. However, this may require a firmware update if the device does not support version 2.

2.19.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0040
  • Classification: Authentication, Clear-Text, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 1058, RFC 1388, RFC 1723, RFC 2453, RFC 4822
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routing_Information_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No RIP Authentication (see section 2.14);
  • No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (see section 2.24).

2.20 Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.20.1 Finding

HTTPS (RFC 2818) provides a cryptographically secure connection for web-based services, such as network device administration and other sensitive services. HTTPS is essentially HTTP (RFC 2616) over an Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)/Transport Layer Security (TLS) (RFC 2546) encrypted connection.

Depending on the implementation, HTTPS can support SSL protocol versions 2, 3, and TLS cryptographic protocols. However, SSL protocol version 2 is now considered to be obsolete and has since been replaced by more secure cryptographic protocols. SSL protocol version 3 has been revealed to contain a number of vulnerabilities, as has TLS v1.0. Additionally, encryption ciphers with key lengths of less than 128 bits are not considered to be as strong as those with higher key lengths.

For example, the significant flaws in the design of SSL version 2 that lead to the improvements in version 3 and TLS included:

  • message authentication and encryption keys were identical;
  • message authentication codes (MAC) relies on the flawed MD5 hashing algorithm;
  • lack of handshake protection;
  • sole reliance on TCP for session termination.

Vulnerabilities with SSL version 3 and TLS version 1.0 making them insecure include:

  • Padding Oracle On Downgraded Legacy Encryption (POODLE) - CVE-2014-3566;
  • Browser Exploit Against SSL/TLS (BEAST) - CVE-2011-3389.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the HTTPS encryption ciphers were SSLv1, SSLv2, SSLv3 and TLSv1 with a key length less than 128 bits.

2.20.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Table 95: Encryption ciphersuites
IANA Name Protocols Key Exchange Authentication Encryption Hash RFC
TLS_RSA_WITH_NULL_SHA SSL v3
TLS v1		 RSA RSA Null SHA-1 RFC 5246

2.20.2 Impact

Although HTTPS provides a significant security enhancement over using a clear-text connection, significant flaws have been identified in SSL versions 2, 3, as well as TLS version 1.0, and the shorter the cipher key length the less time is required to break the encryption. If an attacker is able to monitor or intercept a HTTPS connection that is using one of the weaker protocols or encryption ciphers they could potentially:

  • gain access to the decrypted data and authentication credentials;
  • perform a Man-In-The-Middle (MITM) attack by downgrading the connection;
  • perform a connection truncation attack;
  • perform a POODLE attack.

2.20.3 Ease

Although the vulnerabilities with weak ciphers and encryption protocols are widely known, exploiting the vulnerabilities can be both difficult and time consuming. An attacker who was able to monitor a connection, may require a significant amount of time before even one of the weaker encryption ciphers is broken.

2.20.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that only strong encryption ciphers and protocols should be configured. Nipper recommends that SSL and TLS1.0 should not be used, instead Nipper recommends that you use TLS1.2 instead. Furthermore, Nipper recommends that only encryption ciphers with a key length of at least 128 bits should be used.

2.20.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

The SSL encryption protocol can be restricted to the more secure TLS version 1 or above. Furthermore, the ciphers can be configured to the more secure ciphers with key lengths of at least 128 bits. This can be done with the following commands on versions prior to 9.3(2):

ssl server-version tlsv1.2
ssl client-version tlsv1.2
ssl encryption {3des-sha1 | aes128-sha1 | aes256-sha1}

And the following in versions 9.3(2) and onwards: 

ssl server-version tlsv1.2
ssl client-version tlsv1.2
ssl cipher tlsv1.2 {medium | fips | high}

2.20.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0019
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 2616, RFC 2818, RFC 2546
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Long HTTPS Service Session Idle Timeout (see section 2.11);
  • Weak HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions (see section 2.27).

2.21 User Account Names Contained "admin"

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.21.1 Finding

When User Account names contain "admin", a clear indication is given to an attacker or malicious user that the account most likely has higher privilege levels than a standard user. This allows an attacker to focus their resources in a more direct way, such as targeted phishing attacks or other social engineering techniques.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify usernames that contain "admin".

2.21.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper idenfied one user account that contain "admin" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA. This user accounts is described in the following table:

Table 96: Users containing "admin"
User Password Privilege
admin (ENCRYPTED) 2

2.21.2 Impact

A malicious user would be able to create targeted phishing and social engineering attacks at a specific user they believe to have admin or elevated privileges. Once access is gained, they would have that user's access to a system, which could include re-configuring the device, extracting potentially sensitive information and disabling the device. Once an attacker has obtained the configuration from the device they may be able to identify authentication credentials that could then be used to gain access to other network devices.

2.21.3 Ease

Exploiting this vulnerability would require an attacker to have gained access to sensitive information detailing user accounts and associated ID's before being able to identify appropriate targets for phishing or social engineering attacks.

2.21.4 Recommendation

Nipper strongly recommends that all Admin or elevated privilege accounts should not contain information that identifies them as being such. If possible, those accounts should be renamed.

2.21.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ATH-0025
  • Classification: Authentication

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords (see section 2.3).

2.22 Filter Rules Allow From A Subnet

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.22.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow from a subnet address.

2.22.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "GR" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed from a subnet address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 97: extended ACL: GR
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes officeFTPserver 192.168.0.0/16 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

2.22.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.22.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.22.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.22.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.22.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0019
  • Classification: Filtering

2.23 Filter Rules Allow To A Subnet

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.23.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to a subnet address.

2.23.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "GR" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to a subnet address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 98: extended ACL: GR
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes officeFTPserver 192.168.0.0/16 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "101" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed to a subnet address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 99: extended ACL: 101
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 ftp_servers Any IP any port N/A

Table 100: extended ACL: officeACL1

Table 101: conduit ACL: listy
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.50

2.23.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.23.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.23.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.23.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.23.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0022
  • Classification: Filtering

2.24 No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.24.1 Finding

RIP is a routing protocol that allows network devices to dynamically adapt to changes in the network infrastructure. The routing devices can be configured to send RIP routing updates to specified RIP neighbors. If not specified, RIP routing updates will be sent to all LAN hosts.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that all RIP routing instances were configured with neighbors.

2.24.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that there was one RIP routing instance with no neighbors on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Table 102: RIP routing instances with no neighbors
Router Enabled Send Version Receive Version Update Interval
  Enabled 1 1 0

2.24.2 Impact

With no RIP routing update neighbors configured, route updates will be sent to all LAN hosts. If an attacker is able to monitor a network segment to which the device is attached, they would be able to monitor the routing traffic. This would give the attacker:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.24.3 Ease

RIP routing updates will be sent to all hosts on the LAN. Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can be used to monitor, extract and exploit the information contained in the RIP route update packets.

2.24.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that RIP routing update neighbors should be configured to send RIP updates to specific addresses.

2.24.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0037
  • Classification: Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 1058, RFC 1388, RFC 1723, RFC 2453, RFC 4822
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routing_Information_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No RIP Authentication (see section 2.14);
  • RIP Version 1 Configured (see section 2.19).

2.25 Weak Telnet Service Network Access Restrictions

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.25.1 Finding

The Telnet protocol (described in RFC 15 and RFC 854) is a clear-text protocol that is widely used to provide command-based access to systems and applications. Telnet is a simple protocol that was one of the first TCP/IP protocols to be developed, before security features were given a greater importance.

Network access to the Telnet service can be restricted by specifying those hosts that are allowed to access the service and thereby denying access to all other network host addresses.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that there are no network subnets, or address ranges, configured in the Telnet service specific network access restrictions.

2.25.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified four address entries in the Telnet service host access list on Office-Cisco-ASA that would allow access from entire networks. These are listed in the table below.

Table 103: Network address access entries for the Telnet service
Host
192.168.14.0 192.168.14.254
192.168.14.0/24
10.11.13.0/24
192.168.14.0/24

2.25.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, with valid authentication credentials and access to the service would be able to logon and execute commands within the context of that user. If the attacker does not have authentication credentials they could attempt a brute-force attack in order to identify valid credentials. Additionally, if there is a vulnerability with the service then allowing anyone to connect to the service could enable an attacker to exploit the vulnerability.

2.25.3 Ease

Since the Telnet service was configured to allow access from entire network subnets it would be easier for an unauthorized user, or attacker, to access the service than if Telnet had been restricted to only those specific network addresses that require access. If the attackers address is not within the permitted range they would have to either spoof the address or compromise a system that is within the configured range of network addresses in order to access the service.

2.25.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the clear-text Telnet service should be disabled and a cryptographically secure alternative, such as SSH, be used instead. However, if Telnet access is required, Nipper recommends that access to the Telnet service should be restricted to only those network hosts that require access.

2.25.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

Telnet management hosts can be configured with the following command:

telnet {<hostname> | <ip-address> <interface>}

2.25.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0040
  • Classification: Administration, Clear-Text, Filtering
  • RFCs: RFC 15, RFC 854
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telnet

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No Console Connection Timeout (see section 2.8);
  • Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled (see section 2.9).

It is worth noting that this issue could be mitigated by fixing the following:

  • Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled (see section 2.9).

2.26 Weak SSH Service Network Access Restrictions

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.26.1 Finding

SSH (defined in RFC 4251) is typically used as a cryptographically secure alternative to Telnet and other clear-text protocols. In addition to command-based access, SSH services can enable the forwarding of network ports (such as X forwarding) or the transfer of files (such as SCP or SFTP).

Network access to the SSH service can be restricted by specifying those hosts that are allowed to access the service and thereby denying access to all other network host addresses.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that the SSH service specific network access restrictions limited access to specific administrative hosts.

2.26.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified four address entries in the SSH service host access list on Office-Cisco-ASA that would allow access from entire networks. These are listed in the table below.

Table 104: Network address access entries for the SSH service
Host
192.168.14.0/24
192.168.80.0/24
192.168.1.0/24
192.168.1.0/24

2.26.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, with authentication credentials and access to the service would be able to connect to the SSH service and execute commands within the context of that user. If the attacker does not have authentication credentials they could attempt a brute-force attack in order to identify valid credentials. Additionally, if there is a vulnerability with the service, then allowing anyone to connect to the service could enable an attacker to exploit the vulnerability.

2.26.3 Ease

Since the SSH service was configured to allow access from entire network subnets it would be easier for an unauthorized user, or attacker, to access the service than if SSH had been restricted to only those specific network addresses that require access. If the attackers address is not within the permitted range they would have to either spoof the address or compromise a system that is within the configured range of network addresses in order to access the service.

2.26.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that access to the SSH service should be restricted to only those specific network hosts that require access.

2.26.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

SSH management hosts can be configured with the following command:

ssh <ip-address> <netmask> <interface>

2.26.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0034
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering
  • RFCs: RFC 4250, RFC 4251, RFC 4252, RFC 4253, RFC 4254, RFC 4255, RFC 4256
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSH_(Secure_Shell)

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No Console Connection Timeout (see section 2.8);
  • Long SSH Session Timeout (see section 2.10);
  • SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported (see section 2.15).

2.27 Weak HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.27.1 Finding

HTTPS (RFC 2818) provides a cryptographically secure connection for web-based services, such as network device administration and other sensitive services. HTTPS is a essentially HTTP (RFC 2616) over a SSL/TLS (RFC 2546) encrypted connection.

Network access to the HTTPS service can be restricted by specifying those hosts that are allowed to access the service and thereby denying access to all other network host addresses.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that the HTTPS service specific network access restrictions limited access to only specific administrative host addresses.

2.27.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one entry in the HTTP service host access list on Office-Cisco-ASA that would allow access from an entire network. This is detailed in the table below.

Table 105: Network address access entry for the HTTP service
Host
192.168.1.0/24

2.27.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, with valid authentication credentials and access to the service would be able to connect to the HTTPS service and perform actions within the context of that user. If the attacker does not have authentication credentials they could attempt a brute-force attack in order to identify valid credentials. Additionally, if there is a vulnerability with the service then allowing anyone to connect to the service could enable an attacker to exploit the vulnerability.

2.27.3 Ease

Since the HTTPS service was configured to allow access from entire network subnets it would be easier for an unauthorized user, or attacker, to access the service than if HTTPS had been restricted to only those specific network addresses that require access. If the attackers address is not within the permitted range they would have to either spoof the address or compromise a system that is within the configured range of network addresses in order to access the service.

2.27.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that access to the HTTPS service should be restricted to only those specific network hosts that require access.

2.27.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0048
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering
  • RFCs: RFC 2616, RFC 2818, RFC 2546
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Transfer_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Long HTTPS Service Session Idle Timeout (see section 2.11);
  • Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported (see section 2.20).

2.28 No Post Logon Banner Message

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.28.1 Finding

Post logon banner messages are ones that are shown to users after they have authenticated and prior to being given access to the device. It is one that is shown to users when they connect to a device and prior to the user logon.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the device had a post-login banner message configured.

2.28.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

There was no post-logon banner message configured on Office-Cisco-ASA.

2.28.2 Impact

The post logon banner is useful for detailing the acceptable use policy and the change control procedures which should be followed prior to making any changes to a device's configuration. An acceptable use message detailing the change control procedures and waning against abuse of the policy could help to prevent ad-hoc changes being made to a device's configuration.

2.28.3 Ease

With no post logon banner configured, a user would not be given a reminder of the acceptable use and change control procedure policy details.

2.28.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a post logon banner message is configured that details both the acceptable use policy and change control procedures. Additionally, if the device does not support a pre-logon banner message then Nipper recommends that the post logon banner message should also include a carefully worded legal warning against unauthorized access.

2.28.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

The Exec banner message is displayed once a successful logon has occurred. The Exec banner message can be configured with the following command:

banner exec <message-text>

2.28.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-BAN-0002
  • Classification: Administration

2.29 Filter Rules Allow Any IP

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.29.1 Finding

Network filtering rules are typically configured to enable hosts to access a specific network service or services. Therefore a network filter rule which enables access to a secure web service could be configured to access a specific destination host on TCP port 443. However, it is possible to configure the filter rule to allow access using all IP protocols which, for the previous example, would enable access to port 443 using TCP and UDP.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any filter rules that allow all IP protocols.

2.29.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in LOGtest on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed Any IP. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 106: extended ACL: LOGtest allowing Any IP
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeOUTSIDE OfficeVLAN1 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in GR on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed Any IP. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 107: extended ACL: GR allowing Any IP
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes officeFTPserver 192.168.0.0/16 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in 101 on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed Any IP. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 108: extended ACL: 101 allowing Any IP
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 ftp_servers Any IP any port N/A

2.29.2 Impact

If a network protocol is not specified then it an attacker would not be prevented from accessing hosts and services detailed in the finding using protocols other than those which the services are listening on. This could enable an attacker to gain unauthorized access to a network service or leave unfiltered network ports which an attacker could utilize in a targeted attack.

2.29.3 Ease

With no specific network protocol configured on the network filtering rules identified, access attempts using a network protocol other than the one that was intended would not be prevented by the filtering.

2.29.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all network filter rules should be configured to use only the specific protocols required.

2.29.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0017
  • Classification: Filtering

2.30 Filter Rules Allow ICMP

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.30.1 Finding

Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is an IP protocol that is commonly used by network administrators for network diagnostic purposes. However, ICMP can be used to send a number of different control messages between networked systems, such as destination unreachable, time exceeded, echo request and echo reply (used by the ping utility).

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any filter rules that allow ICMP.

2.30.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper did not identify any filter rule in 2 on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. The configuration of 2 is shown the table below.

Table 109: conduit ACL: 2
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.42

Nipper did not identify any filter rule in extended on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. The configuration of extended is shown the table below.

Table 110: extended ACL: extended
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 80 N/A
2 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 21 N/A

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in GR on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 111: extended ACL: GR allowing ICMP packets
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes officeFTPserver 192.168.0.0/16 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in 101 on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 112: extended ACL: 101 allowing ICMP packets
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 ftp_servers Any IP any port N/A

Nipper did not identify any filter rule in 103 on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. The configuration of 103 is shown the table below.

Table 113: extended ACL: 103
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port a_Office_port to port 80 N/A

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in officeACL1 on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 114: extended ACL: officeACL1 allowing ICMP packets
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Office_admins pad_network_.- protoGROUP any port N/A

Nipper did not identify any filter rule in officeACL2 on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. The configuration of officeACL2 is shown the table below.

Table 115: extended ACL: officeACL2
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 10.100.1.1 10.100.1.2 GRE Level 6

Nipper did not identify any filter rule in 3 on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. The configuration of 3 is shown the table below.

Table 116: extended ACL: 3
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeVLAN1 177.50.1.1 GRE Level 6

Nipper did not identify any filter rule in listy on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. The configuration of listy is shown the table below.

Table 117: conduit ACL: listy
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.50

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in my_accesslist on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 118: extended ACL: my_accesslist allowing ICMP packets
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 my-DNS from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in officeACL3 on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 119: extended ACL: officeACL3 allowing ICMP packets
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 officeService1 from any port to any port N/A

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in Office-access on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed ICMP packets. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 120: extended ACL: Office-access allowing ICMP packets
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

Nipper excluded filter list "LOGtest" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA as it did not contain rules using the appropriate IP version to check for ICMP packets.

2.30.2 Impact

Although ICMP is useful for network administrators who wish to determine if a network device is reachable or is responding, an attacker could also use ICMP to enumerate potential targets. Furthermore, a number of ICMP message types can be used to enumerate basic host and network information. Even the most minor information may be useful to an attacker who may then use that information as part of a targeted attack.

It is worth noting that issues with a host incorrectly processing ICMP messages has been known to lead to a DoS condition.

2.30.3 Ease

Many platforms include a basic set of ICMP tools, such as ping which uses ICMP echo messages. Additionally, a number of more sophisticated ICMP tools can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.30.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, network filter rules should be configured to drop all ICMP traffic.

2.30.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

Specific ICMP message types can be specified for Access Control Entries (ACEs) on Cisco ASA devices using the following command:

access-list <id> extended permit icmp <source> <destination> <icmp-type>

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.30.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0009
  • Classification: Filtering
  • RFCs: RFC 792, RFC 4443
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Control_Message_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Control_Message_Protocol_for_IPv6

2.31 Filter Rules Allow To Port Range

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.31.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to a range port.

2.31.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "listy" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 121: conduit ACL: listy
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.50

2.31.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.31.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.31.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.31.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.31.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0025
  • Classification: Filtering

2.32 No OSPF LSA Thresholds

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.32.1 Finding

Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) is a routing protocol that can be configured to dynamically update the routing table with changes to the network topology. OSPF uses Link State Advertisement (LSA) to communicate changes to other routers and update the routers own Link State Database (LSDB). Devices can be configured with a LSA message threshold in order to limit the number of LSA messages being processed by the device.

Nipper examined the device configuration OSPF routing to determine that a maximum LSA limit had been configured.

2.32.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one OSPF configuration with no maximum LSA configured on Office-Cisco-ASA. This is listed in the table below.

Table 122: OSPF maximum LSA limit
Process Name Router ID IPv6 Maximum LSA
6   No 0

2.32.2 Impact

An attacker may be able to perform an OSPF DoS by flooding the device with LSA messages.

2.32.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can be used to perform a DoS by flooding the device with LSA messages.

2.32.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the number of OSPF LSA messages accepted by the device should be limited.

2.32.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0031
  • Classification: Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 2328, RFC 5340
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Shortest_Path_First

2.33 Clear-Text SNMP In Use

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.33.1 Finding

Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is an industry standard protocol for monitoring and managing a variety of devices. SNMP services typically offer detailed information that includes a device's operating system, network interfaces, memory, system counters and system users. With write access to SNMP, it is possible to re-configure networking, system properties and even shutdown a device.

There are multiple versions of SNMP and versions prior to version 3 offer no encryption of either the authentication or data network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if clear-text SNMP was configured on the device. This includes sending and receiving data for both SNMP versions 1 and 2c.

2.33.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified two SNMP community strings on Office-Cisco-ASA. Those SNMP community string are described in the following table:

Table 123: SNMP Community Strings
Community Access Version
(HIDDEN) Read Only 1
(HIDDEN) Read Only 2c
Table 124: SNMP NMS Hosts
Community Interface Host
(HIDDEN) OfficeOUTSIDE 192.168.20.30
  OfficeVLAN1 10.10.20.20
(HIDDEN) OfficeOUTSIDE 10.20.45.39

2.33.2 Impact

An attacker or malicious user who can monitor the unencrypted SNMP network traffic would capture the SNMP community string used to authenticate access to the SNMP agent service. Additionally, they would capture all the information transferred using the unencrypted connection.

2.33.3 Ease

Network packet capture tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can allow an attacker to monitor the network traffic. In a modern network environment, switches are typically deployed to connect the network infrastructure devices rather than hubs. With network switch devices, the attacker should only be able to see broadcast network traffic or traffic sent directly to or from the attacker's host. However, a skilled attacker could bypass this restriction by performing an attack such as ARP spoofing or exploiting a vulnerability with the network routing. Tools for bypassing a network switching environment's restrictions can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.33.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, SNMP should be disabled. However, if SNMP access is required, Nipper recommends that only SNMP version 3 should be configured with strong authentication and privacy passwords.

2.33.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

SNMP can be disabled with the following command:

no snmp-server

2.33.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0001
  • Classification: Administration, Clear-Text
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.34);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.38).

2.34 No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.34.1 Finding

Using SNMP, some network devices can be instructed to send its configuration to a file on a specified Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) server. This feature enables network administrators and management software to quickly obtain a copy of a device's configuration. A network access list can be configured on those devices to help secure access to this functionality (supported on Cisco Internet Operating System (IOS) devices from version 10.2).

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if a TFTP server ACL had been configured to restrict the SNMP servers TFTP access to specific hosts.

2.34.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that there was no TFTP server ACL configured on Office-Cisco-ASA to restrict the SNMP service access.

2.34.2 Impact

An attacker who had SNMP write access could remotely obtain a copy of a device's configuration. The configuration would include any passwords for the device and include the configuration of the administrative services.

2.34.3 Ease

For an attacker to exploit this issue they would require SNMP query tools, a TFTP server and a community string with write access to the SNMP Management Information Base (MIB). SNMP query tools and TFTP server software can be downloaded from the Internet and some Operating System (OS) install them by default. If the attacker does not know the community string it may be possible to determine it by monitoring the network traffic or by brute-forcing the community string.

2.34.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a SNMP TFTP server list ACL should be configured to ensure that configurations are only saved to specific hosts.

2.34.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0011
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416, RFC 1350
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trivial_File_Transfer_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.33);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.38).

2.35 NTP Authentication Was Disabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.35.1 Finding

Time synchronization for network devices is inherently important, not just for the various services that make use of time, but also for the accurate logging of events. Therefore network devices can be configured to synchronize their time against a network time source in order to ensure that the time is synchronized.

Network Time Protocol (NTP) (described in RFC 5905) is a complex time synchronization protocol with a number of different features and options such as time update authentication.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if NTP authentication was enabled.

2.35.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that the NTP client authentication was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

2.35.2 Impact

If an attacker is able to modify a device's time with an inaccurate time update then it would be more difficult during an examination to correlate the system logs. Furthermore, any systems that depend on accurate time, such as some authentication systems, could be disrupted and potentially cause a DoS.

2.35.3 Ease

With NTP time authentication disabled, an attacker could attempt to update the time by sending malicious time updates. An attacker could do this using open source code or by sending customized network packets and spoofing the source address.

2.35.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that NTP time authentication should be enabled.

2.35.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

To authenticate time synchronization updates, NTP authentication has to be enabled and authentication keys configured. On Cisco ASA devices this can be done with the following commands:

ntp authenticate
ntp trusted-key <key-id>
ntp authentication-key <key-id> md5 <key-string>
ntp server <ip-address> key <key-id>

2.35.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-TME-0002
  • Classification: Authentication
  • RFCs: RFC 1305, RFC 5905
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_Time_Protocol

2.36 Filter Rules Allow To A Network Address Range

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.36.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to a range address.

2.36.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "listy" configured on Office-Cisco-ASA that allowed. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 125: conduit ACL: listy
Rule Action Source
1 192.168.14.50

2.36.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.36.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.36.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.36.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACE can be deleted from an ACL using the following command:

no access-list <access-list-id> <rule>

2.36.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0023
  • Classification: Filtering

2.37 Interfaces Were Configured With No Filtering

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.37.1 Finding

Network filtering is used to restrict access to network services and devices from only those systems that are authorized to access them. For public facing services this could be allowing all remote hosts to connect to a specific service. For remote administrative services this could be to allow only a specific address access to a range of administrative services.

Whilst many devices define filter rules in a single list for the entire device, or network. Some network devices define filter rule lists that are then assigned to specific network interfaces, applying filtering to only the traffic entering or leaving those interfaces.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if inbound or outbound filtering had been configured on all network interfaces.

2.37.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Table 126: Network interfaces with inadequate filtering assigned
Interface Class Active Address Filtering Description
Ethernet0/0 None Yes     Vlan2
None Yes 10.20.0.1
12:34:45:66::21		  

2.37.2 Impact

The network traffic from an attacker attached to one of the network interfaces detailed in the finding would not be subjected to filtering, potentially providing unrestricted access to network services.

2.37.3 Ease

The network traffic would not be subjected to filtering.

2.37.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all network interfaces should be configured with filtering to help prevent unauthorized access to network services and hosts.

2.37.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

An ACL can be configured on an interface with the following command:

access-group <acl> in interface <interface-name>

2.37.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-INTR-0001
  • Classification: Filtering

2.38 Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.38.1 Finding

SNMPv3, like prior versions, provides remote access for the monitoring and administration of a device. Version 3 adds various levels of security and privacy. This enables a SNMPv3 user to have:

  • communication without authentication and privacy encryption (NoAuthNoPriv);
  • communication with authentication hashing and without privacy encryption (AuthNoPriv);
  • communication with authentication hashing and privacy encryption (AuthPriv).

SNMPv3 allows for a variety of different authentication hashing algorithms and privacy encryption algorithms to protect the authentication and data in transit.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if SNMP users were configured to use only FIPS 140-2 authentication hashes.

2.38.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified the following SNMP user on Office-Cisco-ASA that was not configured with FIPS 140-2 compliant authentication hashing.

Table 127: Non FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP user authentication
User Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password
Charles 3 Auth+Priv MD5 (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)

2.38.2 Impact

An attacker who was able to gain access to the authentication hash, possibly by monitoring the network traffic, could attempt to gain access to the password from the hash. With read access to the SNMP MIB an attacker would be able to enumerate a large quantity of information about the device, its configuration, network details and more. With write access to the SNMP MIB an attacker could reconfigure the device, potentially causing a DoS. Additionally, write access to SNMP on some devices would enable an attacker to download a copy of a device's configuration, including password hashes.

2.38.3 Ease

Packet capture tools, password brute force and SNMP management tools can all be downloaded from the Internet. Some OS may install some of those tools by default.

2.38.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a FIPS authentication hashing algorithm should be configured for all SNMPv3 users.

2.38.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0021
  • Classification: Administration, Authentication
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.33);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.34).

2.39 Filter Rule List Does Not End With Drop All And Log

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.39.1 Finding

Network devices that are capable of performing network filtering will usually drop all network traffic when it does not match any of the configured network filter rules. However, this network traffic is also usually excluded from logging when a network filter rule does not apply.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the filter rule list contained an explicit deny all and log to prevent any further network access if a specific allow rule is not defined and log the denied traffic.

2.39.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that "extended" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 128: extended ACL: extended
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 80 N/A
2 Yes 192.168.14.42 192.1.1.1 TCP from any port to port 21 N/A

Nipper determined that "LOGtest" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 129: extended ACL: LOGtest
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeOUTSIDE OfficeVLAN1 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that "GR" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 130: extended ACL: GR
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes officeFTPserver 192.168.0.0/16 Any IP from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that "101" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 131: extended ACL: 101
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 ftp_servers Any IP any port N/A
2 Yes 74.165.236.76 68.156.91.20 TCP from any port to port 23032 N/A

Nipper determined that "103" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 132: extended ACL: 103
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port a_Office_port to port 80 N/A

Nipper determined that "officeACL1" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 133: extended ACL: officeACL1
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes Office_admins pad_network_.- protoGROUP any port N/A

Nipper determined that "officeACL2" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 134: extended ACL: officeACL2
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes 10.100.1.1 10.100.1.2 GRE Level 6

Nipper determined that "3" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 135: extended ACL: 3
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes OfficeVLAN1 177.50.1.1 GRE Level 6

Nipper determined that "my_accesslist" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 136: extended ACL: my_accesslist
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 my-DNS from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that "officeACL3" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 137: extended ACL: officeACL3
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 officeService1 from any port to any port N/A

Nipper determined that "Office-access" on Office-Cisco-ASA did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 138: extended ACL: Office-access
Rule Active Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Yes mNetwork Any IPv4 Office-DNS from any port to any port N/A

2.39.2 Impact

It is common for an attacker to perform network reconnaissance in order to identify potential target hosts and services. An attackers reconnaissance phase can vary greatly in intensity and covertness, but any network scans which do not match the configured filter rules will not be logged.

The log information collected would be useful as evidence in case any legal action were to be taken against the attacker. Without any logging of the network traffic that does not match any of the filter rules, the information would not be recorded for use by network administrators, auditors or a network forensic team.

2.39.3 Ease

Any network traffic that does not match any network filter rules will not be logged.

2.39.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a drop all and log filter rule should be added to filter rule lists to prevent further access and log those attempts.

2.39.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0026
  • Classification: Filtering

2.40 Weak Syslog Severity Level Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.40.1 Finding

Logging is an essential component of a secure network configuration. Logging not only assists network administrators with the identification of issues when troubleshooting, but it also enables network administrators to react to intrusion attempts or DoS attacks. A logging severity level can be configured to specify the severity of the message that will be logged. The standard logging severity levels are:

  • 0 - Emergencies
  • 1 - Alerts
  • 2 - Critical
  • 3 - Errors
  • 4 - Warnings
  • 5 - Notifications
  • 6 - Informational
  • 7 - Debugging

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the Syslog message logging severity level was at least Information severity level.

2.40.2 Impact

If the Syslog severity level is not set to a sufficient level, then important messages may not be logged. This could mean that an attacker's activities are not recoreded for later forensic analysis, or vital troubleshooting information is not available when diagnosing problems with a device.

2.40.3 Ease

The system will not send messages to a Syslog server with a severity level of at least Informational (6).

2.40.4 Recommendation

COMPANY* suggests that the Syslog severity message level should be set to at least Informational (6).

2.40.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-LOG-0008
  • RFCs: RFC 3164, RFC 5424
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syslog

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Syslog Log Destinations Not Using SSL Encryption (see section 2.41).

2.41 Syslog Log Destinations Not Using SSL Encryption

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.41.1 Finding

Syslog logging provides a standard system for logging messages to remote devices, enabling the collection, storage and administration of logs from a variety of devices in a single location. The storage of logs on other systems, not only provides extra storage space for logs which could be size restricted on the original network device, but it also provides an extra level of protection for the logs in a scenario where an attacker has compromised the security of the message source.
