To enhance the confidentiality of the Syslog messages, some devices can deliver messages using SSL encrypted connections to help prevent their contents from being disclosed and leaking potentially sensitive information.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if it was configured to send log messages to all Syslog servers using SSL encrypted connections

2.41.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified the following Syslog logging destinations configured on Office-Cisco-ASA:

Table 139: Syslog hosts
Host Protocol Port Secure
10.100.1.1 UDP 514 No

2.41.2 Impact

With no encryption of the Syslog messages between the client and the Syslog server host, an attacker or malicious user who is able to monitor the network connection could read all the messages sent and capture potentially sensitive information. The Syslog messages will often contain detailed information about the device and the network that an attacker would find useful. Furthermore, the information captured could be used by the attacker as part of a targeted attack.

2.41.3 Ease

The attacker may require physical access to a network segment or routing device between the device where the Syslog messages originate and the Syslog server. In a switched environment the attacker may not be able to monitor the network traffic without performing an ARP spoofing or a routing attack. Tools that are capable of performing these attacks and tools that can monitor network activity can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.41.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, Syslog message sent to logging hosts should only be over SSL encrypted connections.

2.41.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

Cisco ASA devices from OS versions 8.0(2) can be configured to encrypt Syslog messages. Once a Syslog server has been configured to accept encrypted messages, the Cisco ASA device can be configured to encrypt the messages with the following command:

logging host <interface> <ip-address> tcp/<port> secure

2.41.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-LOG-0007
  • RFCs: RFC 3164, RFC 5424
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syslog

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Weak Syslog Severity Level Configured (see section 2.40).

2.42 IPSec With Weak Authentication Hashing Algorithm

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.42.1 Finding

IPsec peers negotiate connections using a number of different protocols, authentication hashing and encryption standards. The authentication hashing is used to verify the data sent between the peers.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all IPSec configurations were configured to use only FIPS 140-2 validated hashing algorithm.

2.42.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified the following IPSec phase-1 configuration on Office-Cisco-ASA with FIPS 140-2 validated hashing algorithm:

Table 140: Phase-1 with FIPS 140-2 validated hashing algorithm
Priority Auth IKE Version Exchange Encryption Hash PRF Mode Lifetime
1 PSK 2 DH Group 5 (1536-bit)
DH Group 2 (1024-bit)		 AES (256-bit) SHA1 SHA1 Main 540 minutes
10 PSK 2 DH Group 5 (1536-bit)
DH Group 2 (1024-bit)		 AES (192-bit) SHA1 SHA1 Main 1440 minutes
20 PSK 2 DH Group 5 (1536-bit)
DH Group 2 (1024-bit)		 AES (128-bit) SHA1 SHA1 Main 1440 minutes
30 PSK 2 DH Group 5 (1536-bit)
DH Group 2 (1024-bit)		 3DES (168-bit) SHA1 SHA1 Main 1440 minutes
40 PSK 2 DH Group 5 (1536-bit)
DH Group 2 (1024-bit)		 DES (56-bit) SHA1 SHA1 Main 1440 minutes
65535 PSK 1 DH Group 2 (1024-bit) AES (128-bit) SHA1 SHA1 Aggr 1440 minutes

Nipper identified the following IPSec transformation set configuration on Office-Cisco-ASA with non-FIPS 140-2 validated hashing algorithm:

Table 141: Transformation set with non-FIPS 140-2 validated hashing algorithm
Name Encryption Hash Mode
ESP-AES-128-MD5 AES (128-bit) MD5 Tunnel
ESP-AES-192-MD5 AES (192-bit) MD5 Tunnel
ESP-AES-256-MD5 AES (256-bit) MD5 Tunnel
ESP-AES-128-MD5-TRANS AES (128-bit) MD5 Transport
ESP-AES-192-MD5-TRANS AES (192-bit) MD5 Transport
ESP-AES-256-MD5-TRANS AES (256-bit) MD5 Transport
ESP-3DES-MD5 3DES (168-bit) MD5 Tunnel
ESP-3DES-MD5-TRANS 3DES (168-bit) MD5 Transport
ESP-DES-MD5 DES (56-bit) MD5 Tunnel
ESP-DES-MD5-TRANS DES (56-bit) MD5 Transport
AES256 AES (256-bit) SHA1
MD5		 Tunnel
AES192 AES (192-bit) SHA1
MD5		 Tunnel
AES AES (128-bit) SHA1
MD5		 Tunnel
3DES 3DES (168-bit) SHA1
MD5		 Tunnel
DES DES (56-bit) SHA1
MD5		 Tunnel

2.42.2 Impact

Although a hashing algorithm had been configured in order to help prevent the tampering of data sent between peers, the hashing algorithm is considered to be weak. With a weak authentication hashing algorithm configured an attacker may be able to break the hash and modify the IPsec VPN traffic sent between two peers.

2.42.3 Ease

A skilled attacker could require a considerable amount of skill and time in order to exploit this issue. The attacker would have to be in a position to be able to monitor a VPN connection in order to intercept network packets containing the hash, break the hash and then be able to send the modified network packets to the receiving peer.

2.42.4 Recommendation

Nipper suggests that a FIPS validated authentication hashing algorithm should be configured for all IPsec VPN connections.

2.42.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-VPN-0005
  • RFCs: RFC 5406
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPsec

The following findings are related to this one:

  • IPSec Aggressive Mode Enabled (see section 2.13);
  • IPSec Configured With Weak Encryption (see section 2.18).

2.43 Unassigned Filter Rule Lists

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.43.1 Finding

Network filter rule lists can be assigned to specific network interfaces, services or protocols on some types of devices. It can be possible on those devices to have network filter rule lists which have not been assigned to anything and are therefore redundant.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that all filter rule lists had been assigned.

2.43.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper determined that the following twelve filter lists on Office-Cisco-ASA were potentially unused:

  • 2
  • extended
  • LOGtest
  • GR
  • 101
  • 103
  • officeACL2
  • 3
  • listy
  • my_accesslist
  • officeACL3
  • Office-access

2.43.2 Impact

Although unused network filter rule lists are not a direct threat to security. However, unused filter rule lists can make interpreting the configured network filtering unclear and potentially lead to the addition of filter rules that enable an attacker to gain unauthorized access to network services.

2.43.3 Ease

An attacker will only be able to exploit this issue if it leads to a network administrator adding additional, or more relaxed, filter rules by mistake. Enabling an attacker to gain unauthorized access to network hosts and services.

2.43.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all unassigned network filter rule lists should be removed.

2.43.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

ACL can be deleted on Cisco ASA devices using the following command:

clear configure access-list <access-list-id>

2.43.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0029
  • Classification: Filtering

2.44 Potentially Unused Network Interfaces

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA

2.44.1 Finding

Many devices enable the activation and deactivation of individual network interfaces. This allows for any unused network interfaces to be disabled. It is generally considered good security practice to disable unused network interfaces to help prevent unauthorized access to the device and network.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the device had any potentially unused interfaces

2.44.1.1 Office-Cisco-ASA Findings

Nipper identified potentially unused network interfaces that were not disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA. The potentially unused interfaces are described in the following table.

Table 142: Potentially unused interfaces that were not disabled
Interface Class Active Address VLAN Trunk Description
Ethernet0/0 None Yes   Vlan2 N/A Ethernet0/1
None Yes   Vlan1 N/A Ethernet0/2 None
Yes   Vlan1 N/A Ethernet0/3 None Yes
  Vlan1 N/A Ethernet0/4 None Yes  
Vlan1 N/A Ethernet0/5 None Yes   Vlan1
N/A Ethernet0/6 None Yes   Vlan1 N/A
Ethernet0/7 None Yes   Vlan1 N/A

2.44.2 Impact

If unused interfaces are not disabled, an attacker may be able to gain access without risking detection by unplugging an existing connection.

2.44.3 Ease

An attacker would require physical access to the device in order to connect to an unused network connection, unless the port has been patched to another location that is more accessible.

2.44.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the list of potentially unused active network connections should be reviewed and any unused interfaces disabled.

2.44.4.1 Cisco ASA Information

Interfaces can be disabled Cisco ASA device using the following command:

interface <interface-name> shutdown

2.44.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-INTR-0002

2.45 Conclusions

Nipper performed a best practice security audit on Friday, September 30, 2022 of the device detailed in Table 143. Nipper identified 42 security-related findings. The most significant finding was rated as critical.

Table 143: Security audit device conclusions
Device Name Issues Highest Rating
Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA 42 Critical

Nipper identified four critical rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • network filter rules allowed access to hosts and services defined on the blacklist (one device, see section 2.2);
  • dictionary-based user authentication credentials were configured (one device, see section 2.3);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access from any source address (one device, see section 2.4);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to any destination address (one device, see section 2.5).

Nipper identified nine high rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • network filter rules were configured that enable access to administrative services (one device, see section 2.6);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to any port (one device, see section 2.7);
  • no console session timeout was configured (one device, see section 2.8);
  • the Telnet service was enabled (one device, see section 2.9);
  • long SSH session timeout was configured (one device, see section 2.10);
  • long HTTPS server session idle timeout was configured (one device, see section 2.11);
  • network filter rules were identified that allow access to clear-text protocol services (one device, see section 2.12);
  • IPsec aggressive mode was configured (one device, see section 2.13);
  • not all RIP configurations were authenticated (one device, see section 2.14).

Nipper identified ten medium rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • support for SSH protocol version 1 was enabled (one device, see section 2.15);
  • network filter rules allowed access to potentially sensitive network services (one device, see section 2.16);
  • network filter rules allowed access to potentially unnecessary network services (one device, see section 2.17);
  • IPsec was configured with support for weak encryption ciphers (one device, see section 2.18);
  • support for RIP version 1 routing updates was configured (one device, see section 2.19);
  • weak encryption ciphers were configured (one device, see section 2.20);
  • user account names were configured that contained "admin" (one device, see section 2.21);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access from a subnet (one device, see section 2.22);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to a subnet (one device, see section 2.23);
  • no RIP routing update neighbors were configured (one device, see section 2.24).

Nipper identified thirteen low rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • weak Telnet network host access addresses were configured (one device, see section 2.25);
  • weak SSH network address access restrictions were configured (one device, see section 2.26);
  • weak HTTPS network host access addresses were configured (one device, see section 2.27);
  • network filter rules were configured to allow all IP protocols (one device, see section 2.29);
  • network filter rules were configured to allow ICMP traffic (one device, see section 2.30);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to a port range (one device, see section 2.31);
  • no OSPF LSA message thresholds were configured (one device, see section 2.32);
  • the clear-text SNMP service was enabled (one device, see section 2.33);
  • a SNMP TFTP server access list was not configured (one device, see section 2.34);
  • NTP authentication was disabled (one device, see section 2.35);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to a network address range (one device, see section 2.36);
  • network interfaces were configured without filtering (one device, see section 2.37);
  • weak SNMPv3 users authentication hashing algorithms were configured (one device, see section 2.38).

Nipper identified six informational rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • not all filter rule lists were configured with a drop all and log rule (one device, see section 2.39);
  • the Syslog server severity level was not set to at least Informational (6) (one device, see section 2.40);
  • Syslog messages were not configured to be sent over SSL encrypted connections (one device, see section 2.41);
  • IPsec was configured with support for a weak authentication hashing algorithm (one device, see section 2.42);
  • unassigned network filter rule lists were configured (one device, see section 2.43);
  • potentially unused interfaces were active (one device, see section 2.44).

Nipper can draw the following statistics from the results of this security assessment (percentages have been rounded). 4 findings (10%) were rated as critical, 9 findings (21%) were rated as high, 10 findings (24%) were rated as medium, 13 findings (31%) were rated as low and 6 findings (14%) were rated as informational.

Severity Classification
[No canvas support]
Issue Classification
[No canvas support]

2.46 Heatmap Analysis

Table 144: Nipper "Impact" to CVSS v2 "Confidentiality"
Informational Low Medium High Critical
Complete 0 0 1 3 2
Partial 1 5 7 7 6
None 4 2 4 0 0

Nipper identified two findings that were rated as both "Critical" for Nipper "Impact" and "Complete" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Critical : Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords (one device, see section 2.3);
  • Medium : SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported (one device, see section 2.15).

Nipper identified three findings that were rated as both "High" for Nipper "Impact" and "Complete" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • High : No Console Connection Timeout (one device, see section 2.8);
  • High : Long SSH Session Timeout (one device, see section 2.10);
  • High : Long HTTPS Service Session Idle Timeout (one device, see section 2.11).

Nipper determined that one finding was identified that was rated as both "Medium" for Nipper "Impact" and "Complete" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". This finding was:

  • Low : No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (one device, see section 2.34).

Nipper identified six findings that were rated as both "Critical" for Nipper "Impact" and "Partial" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Critical : Rules Allow Access To Blacklist Host and Service (one device, see section 2.2);
  • Critical : Filter Rules Allow From Any Source Address (one device, see section 2.4);
  • Critical : Filter Rules Allow To Any Destination Address (one device, see section 2.5);
  • High : Rules Allow Access To Clear-Text Services (one device, see section 2.12);
  • High : IPSec Aggressive Mode Enabled (one device, see section 2.13);
  • Medium : User Account Names Contained "admin" (one device, see section 2.21).

Nipper identified seven findings that were rated as both "High" for Nipper "Impact" and "Partial" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • High : Rules Allow Access To Administrative Services (one device, see section 2.6);
  • High : Filter Rules Allow To Any Port (one device, see section 2.7);
  • High : Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled (one device, see section 2.9);
  • High : No RIP Authentication (one device, see section 2.14);
  • Medium : IPSec Configured With Weak Encryption (one device, see section 2.18);
  • Medium : RIP Version 1 Configured (one device, see section 2.19);
  • Medium : Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported (one device, see section 2.20).

Nipper identified seven findings that were rated as both "Medium" for Nipper "Impact" and "Partial" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Potentially Sensitive Services (one device, see section 2.16);
  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Potentially Unnecessary Services (one device, see section 2.17);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow From A Subnet (one device, see section 2.22);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow To A Subnet (one device, see section 2.23);
  • Medium : No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (one device, see section 2.24);
  • Low : Clear-Text SNMP In Use (one device, see section 2.33);
  • Low : Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (one device, see section 2.38).

Nipper identified five findings that were rated as both "Low" for Nipper "Impact" and "Partial" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Low : Filter Rules Allow Any IP (one device, see section 2.29);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow ICMP (one device, see section 2.30);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow To Port Range (one device, see section 2.31);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow To A Network Address Range (one device, see section 2.36);
  • Low : Interfaces Were Configured With No Filtering (one device, see section 2.37).

Nipper determined that one finding was identified that was rated as both "Informational" for Nipper "Impact" and "Partial" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". This finding was:

  • Informational : Syslog Log Destinations Not Using SSL Encryption (one device, see section 2.41).

Nipper identified four findings that were rated as both "Medium" for Nipper "Impact" and "None" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Low : Weak Telnet Service Network Access Restrictions (one device, see section 2.25);
  • Low : Weak SSH Service Network Access Restrictions (one device, see section 2.26);
  • Low : Weak HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions (one device, see section 2.27);
  • Low : No OSPF LSA Thresholds (one device, see section 2.32).

Nipper identified two findings that were rated as both "Low" for Nipper "Impact" and "None" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Low : NTP Authentication Was Disabled (one device, see section 2.35);
  • Informational : IPSec With Weak Authentication Hashing Algorithm (one device, see section 2.42).

Nipper identified four findings that were rated as both "Informational" for Nipper "Impact" and "None" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Informational : Filter Rule List Does Not End With Drop All And Log (one device, see section 2.39);
  • Informational : Weak Syslog Severity Level Configured (one device, see section 2.40);
  • Informational : Unassigned Filter Rule Lists (one device, see section 2.43);
  • Informational : Potentially Unused Network Interfaces (one device, see section 2.44).

2.47 Recommendations

This section collates the issue recommendations into a single location in order to provide a guide to planning and mitigating the identified issues. The recommendations are listed in Table 145 together with the issue rating and a list of affected devices.

Table 145: Security audit recommendations list
Issue Rating Recommendation Affected Devices Section
Rules Allow Access To Blacklist Host and Service Critical Modify the filter rules to prevent access to blacklist host and services Office-Cisco-ASA 2.2
Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords Critical Configure strong passwords for all user authentication credentials. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.3
Filter Rules Allow From Any Source Address Critical Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access Office-Cisco-ASA 2.4
Filter Rules Allow To Any Destination Address Critical Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access Office-Cisco-ASA 2.5
Rules Allow Access To Administrative Services High Modify the filter rules to only permit access to administrative services where it is necessary Office-Cisco-ASA 2.6
Filter Rules Allow To Any Port High Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access Office-Cisco-ASA 2.7
No Console Connection Timeout High Configure a console session timeout of at most 10 minutes. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.8
Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled High Disable the Telnet service. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.9
Long SSH Session Timeout High Configure an SSH session timeout of at most 10 minutes. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.10
Long HTTPS Service Session Idle Timeout High Configure a HTTPS server session idle timeout of at most 10 minutes. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.11
Rules Allow Access To Clear-Text Services High Modify the filter rules to prevent access to clear-text protocol services Office-Cisco-ASA 2.12
IPSec Aggressive Mode Enabled High Configure main mode for all IPsec VPN connections Office-Cisco-ASA 2.13
No RIP Authentication High Configure strong authentication keys for all RIP routing updates Office-Cisco-ASA 2.14
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported Medium Configure the SSH service to support only version 2 of the protocol. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.15
Rules Allow Access To Potentially Sensitive Services Medium Modify the filter rules to restrict access to potentially sensitive network services Office-Cisco-ASA 2.16
Rules Allow Access To Potentially Unnecessary Services Medium Modify the filter rules to prevent access to potentially unnecessary network services Office-Cisco-ASA 2.17
IPSec Configured With Weak Encryption Medium Configure a FIPS validated encryption algorithm for all IPsec VPN connections Office-Cisco-ASA 2.18
RIP Version 1 Configured Medium Configure support for RIP version 2 only.
Migrate to a device that has support for RIP version 2.		 Office-Cisco-ASA 2.19
Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported Medium Configure only strong encryption ciphers. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.20
User Account Names Contained "admin" Medium Ensure administrative or elevated privilege accounts do not contain information identifying them as such. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.21
Filter Rules Allow From A Subnet Medium Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access Office-Cisco-ASA 2.22
Filter Rules Allow To A Subnet Medium Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access Office-Cisco-ASA 2.23
No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured Medium Configure RIP routing update neighbors Office-Cisco-ASA 2.24
Weak Telnet Service Network Access Restrictions Low Use a cryptographically secure alternative to Telnet, such as SSH.
Disable access to the Telnet service
OR
Restrict the Telnet service to only those specific hosts that require access.		 Office-Cisco-ASA 2.25
Weak SSH Service Network Access Restrictions Low Restrict the SSH service to only those hosts that require access. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.26
Weak HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions Low Restrict the HTTPS service to only those specific hosts that require access. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.27
Filter Rules Allow Any IP Low Modify the filter rules to use a specific protocol Office-Cisco-ASA 2.29
Filter Rules Allow ICMP Low Modify the filter rules to drop all ICMP network traffic Office-Cisco-ASA 2.30
Filter Rules Allow To Port Range Low Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access Office-Cisco-ASA 2.31
No OSPF LSA Thresholds Low Configure OSPF LSA message thresholds for all OSPF routing processes Office-Cisco-ASA 2.32
Clear-Text SNMP In Use Low Disable access to the clear-text SNMP service.
Configure SNMP version 3 with authentication and privacy passwords instead of SNMP versions 1 or 2.		 Office-Cisco-ASA 2.33
No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured Low Configure a SNMP TFTP server access list. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.34
NTP Authentication Was Disabled Low Enable NTP authentication. Office-Cisco-ASA 2.35
Filter Rules Allow To A Network Address Range Low Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access Office-Cisco-ASA 2.36
Interfaces Were Configured With No Filtering Low Assign network filtering rules to all network interfaces Office-Cisco-ASA 2.37
Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured Low Configure a FIPS authentication hashing algorithm for all SNMPv3 users Office-Cisco-ASA 2.38
Filter Rule List Does Not End With Drop All And Log Informational Add a drop all and log filter rule as the last filter rule Office-Cisco-ASA 2.39
Weak Syslog Severity Level Configured Informational Configure the Syslog severity level to at least Informational (6) Office-Cisco-ASA 2.40
Syslog Log Destinations Not Using SSL Encryption Informational Configure Syslog to only send messages over SSL encrypted connections Office-Cisco-ASA 2.41
IPSec With Weak Authentication Hashing Algorithm Informational Configure a FIPS validated authentication hashing algorithm for all IPsec VPN connections Office-Cisco-ASA 2.42
Unassigned Filter Rule Lists Informational Remove all unused network filter rule lists Office-Cisco-ASA 2.43
Potentially Unused Network Interfaces Informational Disable all unused interfaces Office-Cisco-ASA 2.44

2.48 Mitigation Classification

This section aims to provide a guide to the perceived complexity of resolving a particular finding by implementing the recommendation. An outline of how each mitigation classification has been determined is described in Table 146.

Table 146: The mitigation classification
Classification Description
Quick The finding is quick to resolve. Typically this would just involve changing a small number of settings and would have little-to-no effect on network services.
Planned The finding resolution involves planning, testing and could cause some disruption to services. This finding could involve changes to routing protocols and changes to network filtering.
Involved The resolution of the finding will require significant resources to resolve and is likely to include disruption to network services, and possibly the modification of other network device configurations. The finding could involve upgrading a device's OS and possible modifications to the hardware.

Nipper identified 18 security findings with mitigation recommendations that were classified as Quick. Those findings were:

  • Critical : Rules Allow Access To Blacklist Host and Service (one device, see section 2.2);
  • Critical : Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords (one device, see section 2.3);
  • High : No Console Connection Timeout (one device, see section 2.8);
  • High : Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled (one device, see section 2.9);
  • High : Long SSH Session Timeout (one device, see section 2.10);
  • High : Long HTTPS Service Session Idle Timeout (one device, see section 2.11);
  • Medium : SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported (one device, see section 2.15);
  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Potentially Sensitive Services (one device, see section 2.16);
  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Potentially Unnecessary Services (one device, see section 2.17);
  • Medium : Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported (one device, see section 2.20);
  • Medium : User Account Names Contained "admin" (one device, see section 2.21);
  • Low : Weak HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions (one device, see section 2.27);
  • Low : No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (one device, see section 2.34);
  • Low : Interfaces Were Configured With No Filtering (one device, see section 2.37);
  • Informational : Filter Rule List Does Not End With Drop All And Log (one device, see section 2.39);
  • Informational : Weak Syslog Severity Level Configured (one device, see section 2.40);
  • Informational : Unassigned Filter Rule Lists (one device, see section 2.43);
  • Informational : Potentially Unused Network Interfaces (one device, see section 2.44).

Nipper identified 23 security findings with mitigation recommendations that were classified as Planned. Those findings were:

  • Critical : Filter Rules Allow From Any Source Address (one device, see section 2.4);
  • Critical : Filter Rules Allow To Any Destination Address (one device, see section 2.5);
  • High : Rules Allow Access To Administrative Services (one device, see section 2.6);
  • High : Filter Rules Allow To Any Port (one device, see section 2.7);
  • High : Rules Allow Access To Clear-Text Services (one device, see section 2.12);
  • High : IPSec Aggressive Mode Enabled (one device, see section 2.13);
  • High : No RIP Authentication (one device, see section 2.14);
  • Medium : IPSec Configured With Weak Encryption (one device, see section 2.18);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow From A Subnet (one device, see section 2.22);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow To A Subnet (one device, see section 2.23);
  • Medium : No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (one device, see section 2.24);
  • Low : Weak Telnet Service Network Access Restrictions (one device, see section 2.25);
  • Low : Weak SSH Service Network Access Restrictions (one device, see section 2.26);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow Any IP (one device, see section 2.29);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow ICMP (one device, see section 2.30);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow To Port Range (one device, see section 2.31);
  • Low : No OSPF LSA Thresholds (one device, see section 2.32);
  • Low : Clear-Text SNMP In Use (one device, see section 2.33);
  • Low : NTP Authentication Was Disabled (one device, see section 2.35);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow To A Network Address Range (one device, see section 2.36);
  • Low : Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (one device, see section 2.38);
  • Informational : Syslog Log Destinations Not Using SSL Encryption (one device, see section 2.41);
  • Informational : IPSec With Weak Authentication Hashing Algorithm (one device, see section 2.42).

Nipper identified one security finding with a mitigation recommendation that was classified as Involved. This finding was:

  • Medium : RIP Version 1 Configured (one device, see section 2.19).

Nipper can draw the following additional conclusion from the best practice security audit based on the classification of the recommended finding mitigations. Of the 42 security findings identified, 18 (42%) recommendations were classified as having a quick mitigation, 23 (54%) recommendations were classified as having a planned mitigation and one (2%) recommendation was classified as having a involved mitigation.

Issue Mitigation Classification
[No canvas support]

3.2.2 SRG-APP-000142-NDM-000245

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239911
  • Rule ID : SV-239911r666096_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000382
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000430
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.2.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to prohibit the use of all unnecessary and/or non-secure functions, ports, protocols, and/or services.

3.2.2.2 Discussion

In order to prevent unauthorized connection of devices, unauthorized transfer of information, or unauthorized tunneling (i.e., embedding of data types within data types), organizations must disable unused or unnecessary physical and logical ports/protocols on information systems.

Network devices are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services provided by default may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations. Additionally, it is sometimes convenient to provide multiple services from a single component (e.g., email and web services); however, doing so increases risk over limiting the services provided by any one component.

To support the requirements and principles of least functionality, the network device must support the organizational requirements providing only essential capabilities and limiting the use of ports, protocols, and/or services to only those required, authorized, and approved. Some network devices have capabilities enabled by default; if these capabilities are not necessary, they must be disabled. If a particular capability is used, then it must be documented and approved.

3.2.2.3 Check

Verify the ASA does not have any unnecessary or non-secure ports, protocols, and services enabled. For example, the following features such as telnet should never be enabled, while other features should only be enabled if required for operations. In the example below, http and telnet service are enabled.

http server enable



telnet 10.1.22.2 255.255.255.255 INSIDE

Note: The command http server enables https and is required for ASDM.

If any unnecessary or non-secure ports, protocols, or services are enabled, this is a finding.

3.2.2.4 Findings

3.2.2.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

[FAIL]

Nipper examined the remote administrative services configured on Office-Cisco-ASA to determine their state and authorization. The status of each service is detailed in the following table:

Table 150: Authorization state of administrative services on Office-Cisco-ASA
Service Authorized State Status
Telnet No Enabled Fail
Clear-Text Web Administration (HTTP) No Disabled Pass

3.2.2.5 Fix

Disable features that should not be enabled unless required for operations.

ASA(config)# no http server enable
ASA(config)# no telnet 10.1.22.2 255.255.255.255 INSIDE
ASA(config)# end

Note: Telnet must always be disabled.

3.2.2.6 CCI References

The organization configures the information system to prohibit or restrict the use of organization-defined functions, ports, protocols, and/or services.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - CM-7;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - CM-7.1 (iii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - CM-7 b.

3.2.2.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000382
  • Fix ID : F-43103r666095_fix
  • Check ID : C-43144r666094_chk

3.2.3 SRG-APP-000190-NDM-000267

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239920
  • Rule ID : SV-239920r666196_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001133
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000690
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.3.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to terminate all network connections associated with a device management session at the end of the session, or the session must be terminated after 10 minutes of inactivity except to fulfill documented and validated mission requirements.

3.2.3.2 Discussion

Terminating an idle session within a short time period reduces the window of opportunity for unauthorized personnel to take control of a management session enabled on the console or console port that has been left unattended. In addition, quickly terminating an idle session will also free up resources committed by the managed network element.

Terminating network connections associated with communications sessions includes, for example, de-allocating associated TCP/IP address/port pairs at the operating system level, or de-allocating networking assignments at the application level if multiple application sessions are using a single, operating system-level network connection. This does not mean that the device terminates all sessions or network access; it only ends the inactive session and releases the resources associated with that session.

3.2.3.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify all network connections associated with a device management have an idle timeout value set to 10 minutes or less as shown in the following example:

http server idle-timeout 10



ssh timeout 10



console timeout 10

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to terminate all network connections associated with a device management after 10 minutes of inactivity, this is a finding.

3.2.3.4 Findings

3.2.3.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that the SSH service idle session timeout configured on Office-Cisco-ASA was set to 50 minutes.

[N/A]

Table 151: Web-based administration service settings
Description Value
Web Administration Service (HTTP) Disabled
HTTP TCP Port 80
Web Administration Service Secure Redirect Enabled
Administrative Hosts Required Yes

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that there was no console session timeout set on Office-Cisco-ASA.

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that the HTTPS service specific timeout configured on Office-Cisco-ASA was set to 300 minutes.

3.2.3.5 Fix

Set the idle timeout value to 10 minutes or less for console, ssh, and http (if ASDM is used) access.

SW1(config)# ssh timeout 10
SW1(config)# console timeout 10
ASA(config)# http server idle-timeout 10
SW1(config)# end

3.2.3.6 CCI References

The information system terminates the network connection associated with a communications session at the end of the session or after an organization-defined time period of inactivity.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - SC-10;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - SC-10.1 (ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - SC-10.

3.2.3.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001133
  • Fix ID : F-43112r666122_fix
  • Check ID : C-43153r666121_chk

3.2.4 SRG-APP-000411-NDM-000330

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239930
  • Rule ID : SV-239930r666153_rule
  • CCI : CCI-002890
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001140
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.4.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to use FIPS-validated Keyed-Hash Message Authentication Code (HMAC) to protect the integrity of non-local maintenance and diagnostic communications.

3.2.4.2 Discussion

Unapproved mechanisms that are used for authentication to the cryptographic module are not verified and therefore cannot be relied upon to provide confidentiality or integrity, and DoD data may be compromised.

Non-local maintenance and diagnostic activities are those activities conducted by individuals communicating through a network, either an external network (e.g., the internet) or an internal network.

Currently, HMAC is the only FIPS-approved algorithm for generating and verifying message/data authentication codes in accordance with FIPS 198-1. Products that are FIPS 140-2 validated will have an HMAC that meets specification; however, the option must be configured for use as the only message authentication code used for authentication to cryptographic modules.

Separate requirements for configuring applications and protocols used by each application (e.g., SNMPv3, SSHv2, NTP, HTTPS, and other protocols and applications that require server/client authentication) are required to implement this requirement. Where SSH is used, the SSHv2 protocol suite is required because it includes Layer 7 protocols such as SCP and SFTP, which can be used for secure file transfers.

3.2.4.3 Check

SSH Example

Step 1: Verify that FIPS mode is enabled as shown in the example below. 

fips enable

Step 2: Verify that SSH is configured to only use FIPS-compliant ciphers and that Diffie-Hellman Group 14 is used for the key exchange as shown in the example below.

ssh version 2
ssh cipher encryption fips
ssh key-exchange group dh-group14-sha1

Note: The ASA only supports SSHv2.

SNMP Example

snmp-server group NETOPS v3 auth
snmp-server user FWADMIN NETOPS v3 engineID xxxxxxxxxxxx encrypted auth sha xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
snmp-server host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10 version 3 FWADMIN

If the ASA is not configured to implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of remote maintenance sessions using a FIPS 140-2 approved algorithm, this is a finding.

3.2.4.4 Findings

3.2.4.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that FIPS mode was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

[FAIL]

Nipper detemined that the SSH service was configured to support versions 1 and 2 of the protocol on Office-Cisco-ASA.

[FAIL]

Nipper detemined that the SSH service was configured to support versions 1 and 2 of the protocol on Office-Cisco-ASA.

[FAIL]

Nipper identified two SNMP community strings on Office-Cisco-ASA. Those SNMP community string are described in the following table:

Table 152: SNMP Community Strings
Community Access Version
(HIDDEN) Read Only 1
(HIDDEN) Read Only 2c
Table 153: SNMP NMS Hosts
Community Interface Host
(HIDDEN) OfficeOUTSIDE 192.168.20.30
  OfficeVLAN1 10.10.20.20
(HIDDEN) OfficeOUTSIDE 10.20.45.39

Nipper identified the following SNMP user on Office-Cisco-ASA that was not configured with FIPS 140-2 compliant authentication hashing.

Table 154: Non FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP user authentication
User Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password
Charles 3 Auth+Priv MD5 (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)

Nipper identified the following two SNMP users on Office-Cisco-ASA that were configured to use a FIPS 140-2 compliant privacy encryption algorithm.

Table 155: FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP user privacy
User Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password
Tom 3 Auth+Priv SHA (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)
Charles 3 Auth+Priv MD5 (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)
Table 156: Non FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP trap/inform hosts
Host Version Community Port Interface
1.1.1.1 1 (HIDDEN) 162 OfficeOUTSIDE

3.2.4.5 Fix

SSH Example

Step 1: Enable FIPS mode via the fips enable command.

Step 2: Configure SSH to only use FIPS-compliant ciphers and Diffie-Hellman Group 14 for the key exchange.

ASA(config)# ssh cipher encryption fips 
ASA(config)# ssh key-exchange group dh-group14-sha

SNMP Example

ASA(config)# snmp-server group NETOPS v3 auth
ASA(config)# snmp-server user FWADMIN NETOPS v3 auth sha xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
ASA(config)# snmp-server host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10 version 3 FWADMIN
ASA(config)# end

3.2.4.6 CCI References

The information system implements cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic communications.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - MA-4 (6).

3.2.4.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-002890
  • Fix ID : F-43122r666152_fix
  • Check ID : C-43163r666151_chk

3.2.5 SRG-APP-000412-NDM-000331

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239931
  • Rule ID : SV-239931r666156_rule
  • CCI : CCI-003123
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001150
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.5.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to implement cryptographic mechanisms using a FIPS 140-2 approved algorithm to protect the confidentiality of remote maintenance sessions.

3.2.5.2 Discussion

This requires the use of secure protocols instead of their unsecured counterparts, such as SSH instead of telnet, SCP instead of FTP, and HTTPS instead of HTTP. If unsecured protocols (lacking cryptographic mechanisms) are used for sessions, the contents of those sessions will be susceptible to eavesdropping, potentially putting sensitive data (including administrator passwords) at risk of compromise and potentially allowing hijacking of maintenance sessions.

3.2.5.3 Check

Step 1: Verify FIPS mode is enabled as shown in the example below. 

fips enable

Step 2: Verify that only SSH is configured to only use FIPS-compliant ciphers and that Diffie-Hellman Group 14 is used for the key exchange as shown in the example below.

ssh version 2
ssh cipher encryption fips
ssh key-exchange group dh-group14-sha1

Note: The ASA only supports SSHv2.

If the ASA is not configured to implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of remote maintenance sessions using a FIPS 140-2 approved algorithm, this is a finding.

3.2.5.4 Findings

3.2.5.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that FIPS mode was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

[FAIL]

Nipper detemined that the SSH service was configured to support versions 1 and 2 of the protocol on Office-Cisco-ASA.

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that the SSH key exchange group was set to DH Group 1 SHA1 on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.5.5 Fix

Step 1: Enable FIPS mode via the fips enable command.

Step 2: Configure SSH to only use FIPS-compliant ciphers and Diffie-Hellman Group 14 for the key exchange.

ASA(config)# ssh cipher encryption fips 
ASA(config)# ssh key-exchange group dh-group14-sha

3.2.5.6 CCI References

The information system implements cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic communications.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - MA-4 (6).

3.2.5.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-003123
  • Fix ID : F-43123r666155_fix
  • Check ID : C-43164r666154_chk

3.2.6 SRG-APP-000516-NDM-000336

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239940
  • Rule ID : SV-239940r666183_rule
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001310
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.6.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to use an authentication server to authenticate users prior to granting administrative access.

3.2.6.2 Discussion

Centralized management of authentication settings increases the security of remote and non-local access methods. This control is particularly important protection against the insider threat. With robust centralized management, audit records for administrator account access to the organization's network devices can be more readily analyzed for trends and anomalies. The alternative method of defining administrator accounts on each device exposes the device configuration to remote access authentication attacks and system administrators with multiple authenticators for each network device.

3.2.6.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify the device is configured to use an authentication server as primary source for authentication.

Step 1: Verify that an AAA group is configured for login authentication for both in-band and console access methods.

aaa authentication serial console RADIUS_GROUP LOCAL
aaa authentication ssh console RADIUS_GROUP LOCAL

Step 2: Verify that an AAA group and server has been defined for the group referenced in the above example.

aaa-server RADIUS_GROUP protocol radius
aaa-server RADIUS_GROUP (NDM_INTERFACE) host 10.1.48.10
 key *****

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to use an authentication server for the purpose of authenticating users prior to granting administrative access, this is a finding.

3.2.6.4 Findings

3.2.6.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that Authentication, Authorization and Accounting (AAA) authentication ordering was not configured on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.6.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to use an authentication server as shown in the following example.

Step 1: Define the authentication group and protocol.

ASA(config)# aaa-server RADIUS_GROUP protocol radius

Step 2: Define the authentication server. 

ASA(config)# aaa-server RADIUS_GROUP (NDM_INTERFACE) host 10.1.48.10         
ASA(config-aaa-server-host)# key bobby
ASA(config-aaa-server-host)# exit

Step 3: Use the AAA server for login authentication for both in-band and console access methods.

ASA(config)# aaa authentication serial console RADIUS_GROUP LOCAL
ASA(config)# aaa authentication ssh console RADIUS_GROUP LOCAL
ASA(config)# end

3.2.6.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000370, CCI-000366
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000370, CCI-000366
  • Fix ID : F-43132r666182_fix
  • Check ID : C-43173r666181_chk

3.2.7 SRG-APP-000516-NDM-000350

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239943
  • Rule ID : SV-239943r666192_rule
  • CCI : CCI-002605
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001410
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Pass)

3.2.7.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to send log data to a central log server for the purpose of forwarding alerts to organization-defined personnel and/or the firewall administrator.

3.2.7.2 Discussion

The aggregation of log data kept on a syslog server can be used to detect attacks and trigger an alert to the appropriate security personnel. The stored log data can used to detect weaknesses in security that enable the network IA team to find and address these weaknesses before breaches can occur. Reviewing these logs, whether before or after a security breach, are important in showing whether someone is an internal employee or an outside threat. The ISSM or ISSO may designate the firewall/system administrator or other authorized personnel to receive the alert within the specified time, validate the alert, and then forward only validated alerts to the ISSM and ISSO.

3.2.7.3 Check

Verify the ASA is configured to send logs to a syslog server. The configuration should look similar to the example below.

logging trap notifications
logging host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10 6/1514

Note: A logging list can be used as an alternative to the severity level.

If the ASA is not configured to send log data to the syslog server, this is a finding.

3.2.7.4 Findings

3.2.7.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that logging to a Syslog server was enabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Table 157: Syslog hosts
Host Protocol Port Secure
10.100.1.1 UDP 514 No

3.2.7.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to send log messages to the syslog server as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10 6/1514
ASA(config)# logging trap notifications
ASA(config)# end

3.2.7.6 CCI References

The organization installs security-relevant software updates within an organization-defined time period of the release of the updates.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - SI-2 c.

3.2.7.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-002605
  • Fix ID : F-43135r666191_fix
  • Check ID : C-43176r666190_chk

3.2.8 SRG-APP-000516-NDM-000351

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239944
  • Rule ID : SV-239944r666195_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000366
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001420
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Investigate)

3.2.8.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be running an operating system release that is currently supported by Cisco Systems.

3.2.8.2 Discussion

Network devices running an unsupported operating system lack current security fixes required to mitigate the risks associated with recent vulnerabilities.

3.2.8.3 Check

Verify the ASA is in compliance with this requirement by having the ASA administrator enter the following command.

show version

Verify the release is still supported by Cisco. All releases supported by Cisco can be found at the following URL:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/asa-firepower-services/eos-eol-notice-listing.html

If the ASA is not running a supported release, this is a finding.

3.2.8.4 Fix

Upgrade the ASA to a supported release.

3.2.8.5 CCI References

The organization implements the security configuration settings.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - CM-6 b;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - CM-6.1 (iv);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - CM-6 b.

3.2.8.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000366
  • Fix ID : F-43136r666194_fix
  • Check ID : C-43177r666193_chk

3.2.9 SRG-APP-000001-NDM-000200

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239896
  • Rule ID : SV-239896r666051_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000054
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000010
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.9.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to limit the number of concurrent management sessions to an organization-defined number.

3.2.9.2 Discussion

Device management includes the ability to control the number of administrators and management sessions that manage a device. Limiting the number of allowed administrators and sessions per administrator based on account type, role, or access type is helpful in limiting risks related to DoS attacks.

This requirement addresses concurrent sessions for administrative accounts and does not address concurrent sessions by a single administrator via multiple administrative accounts. The maximum number of concurrent sessions should be defined based upon mission needs and the operational environment for each system. At a minimum, limits must be set for SSH, HTTPS, account of last resort, and root account sessions.

3.2.9.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to determine if concurrent management sessions are limited as show in the example below:

quota management-session 2

Note: This requirement is not applicable to file transfer actions such as FTP, SCP, and SFTP. The default is 5 sessions, which would not be shown in the configuration unless the show run all command is used.

If the ASA is not configured to limit the number of concurrent management sessions, this is a finding.

3.2.9.4 Findings

3.2.9.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that there was no administrative service session limit configured on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.9.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to limit the number of concurrent management sessions to an organization-defined number as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# quota management-session 2

3.2.9.6 CCI References

The information system limits the number of concurrent sessions for each organization-defined account and/or account type to an organization-defined number of sessions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-10;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-10.1 (ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-10.

3.2.9.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000054
  • Fix ID : F-43088r666050_fix
  • Check ID : C-43129r666049_chk

3.2.10 SRG-APP-000026-NDM-000208

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239897
  • Rule ID : SV-239897r666054_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000018
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000090
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.10.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to automatically audit account creation.

3.2.10.2 Discussion

Upon gaining access to a network device, an attacker will often first attempt to create a persistent method of reestablishing access. One way to accomplish this is to create a new account. Notification of account creation helps to mitigate this risk. Auditing account creation provides the necessary reconciliation that account management procedures are being followed. Without this audit trail, personnel without the proper authorization may gain access to critical network nodes.

3.2.10.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to determine if it automatically audits account creation. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands.

If account creation is not automatically audited, this is a finding.

3.2.10.4 Findings

3.2.10.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.10.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to log account creation using the following commands:

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.10.6 CCI References

The information system automatically audits account creation actions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-2 (4);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-2 (4).1 (i and ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-2 (4).

3.2.10.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000018
  • Fix ID : F-43089r666053_fix
  • Check ID : C-43130r666052_chk

3.2.11 SRG-APP-000027-NDM-000209

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239898
  • Rule ID : SV-239898r666057_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001403
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000100
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.11.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to automatically audit account modification.

3.2.11.2 Discussion

Since the accounts in the network device are privileged or system-level accounts, account management is vital to the security of the network device. Account management by a designated authority ensures access to the network device is being controlled in a secure manner by granting access to only authorized personnel with the appropriate and necessary privileges. Auditing account modification along with an automatic notification to appropriate individuals will provide the necessary reconciliation that account management procedures are being followed. If modifications to management accounts are not audited, reconciliation of account management procedures cannot be tracked.

3.2.11.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to determine if it automatically audits account modification. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands.

If account modification is not automatically audited, this is a finding.

3.2.11.4 Findings

3.2.11.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.11.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to log account modification using the following commands:

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.11.6 CCI References

The information system automatically audits account modification actions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-2 (4);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-2 (4).1 (i and ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-2 (4).

3.2.11.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001403
  • Fix ID : F-43090r666056_fix
  • Check ID : C-43131r666055_chk

3.2.12 SRG-APP-000028-NDM-000210

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239899
  • Rule ID : SV-239899r666060_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001404
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000110
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.12.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to automatically audit account disabling actions.

3.2.12.2 Discussion

Account management, as a whole, ensures access to the network device is being controlled in a secure manner by granting access to only authorized personnel. Auditing account disabling actions will support account management procedures. When device management accounts are disabled, user or service accessibility may be affected. Auditing also ensures authorized active accounts remain enabled and available for use when required.

3.2.12.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to determine if it automatically audits account disabling. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands.

If account disabling is not automatically audited, this is a finding.

3.2.12.4 Findings

3.2.12.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.12.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to log account disabling using the following commands:

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.12.6 CCI References

The information system automatically audits account disabling actions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-2 (4);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-2 (4).1 (i and ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-2 (4).

3.2.12.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001404
  • Fix ID : F-43091r666059_fix
  • Check ID : C-43132r666058_chk

3.2.13 SRG-APP-000029-NDM-000211

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239900
  • Rule ID : SV-239900r666063_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001405
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000120
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.13.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to automatically audit account removal actions.

3.2.13.2 Discussion

Account management, as a whole, ensures access to the network device is being controlled in a secure manner by granting access to only authorized personnel. Auditing account removal actions will support account management procedures. When device management accounts are terminated, user or service accessibility may be affected. Auditing also ensures authorized active accounts remain enabled and available for use when required.

3.2.13.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to determine if it automatically audits account removal. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands.

If account removal is not automatically audited, this is a finding.

3.2.13.4 Findings

3.2.13.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.13.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to log account removal using the following commands:

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.13.6 CCI References

The information system automatically audits account removal actions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-2 (4);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-2 (4).1 (i and ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-2 (4).

3.2.13.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001405
  • Fix ID : F-43092r666062_fix
  • Check ID : C-43133r666061_chk

3.2.14 SRG-APP-000038-NDM-000213

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239901
  • Rule ID : SV-239901r666066_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001368
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000140
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Pass)

3.2.14.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to enforce approved authorizations for controlling the flow of management information within the Cisco ASA based on information flow control policies.

3.2.14.2 Discussion

A mechanism to detect and prevent unauthorized communication flow must be configured or provided as part of the system design. If management information flow is not enforced based on approved authorizations, the network device may become compromised. Information flow control regulates where management information is allowed to travel within a network device. The flow of all management information must be monitored and controlled so it does not introduce any unacceptable risk to the network device or data.

Application-specific examples of enforcement occur in systems that employ rule sets or establish configuration settings that restrict information system services or message-filtering capability based on message content (e.g., implementing key word searches or using document characteristics).

Applications providing information flow control must be able to enforce approved authorizations for controlling the flow of management information within the system in accordance with applicable policy.

3.2.14.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that management access is restricted to specific IP address space as shown in the example below.

ssh x.x.x.0 255.255.255.0 INSIDE

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to enforce approved authorizations for controlling the flow of management information within the device based on control policies, this is a finding.

3.2.14.4 Findings

3.2.14.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

The configuration of SSH service specific administrative hosts is not supported on Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall devices.

3.2.14.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to restrict management access to specific IP addresses via SSH as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# ssh x.x.x.0 255.255.255.0 INSIDE
ASA(config)# end

3.2.14.6 CCI References

The information system enforces approved authorizations for controlling the flow of information within the system based on organization-defined information flow control policies.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-4;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-4.1 (iii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-4.

3.2.14.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001368
  • Fix ID : F-43093r666065_fix
  • Check ID : C-43134r666064_chk

3.2.15 SRG-APP-000068-NDM-000215

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239902
  • Rule ID : SV-239902r666069_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000048
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000160
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.15.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to display the Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner before granting access to the device.

3.2.15.2 Discussion

Display of the DoD-approved use notification before granting access to the network device ensures privacy and security notification verbiage used is consistent with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance.

System use notifications are required only for access via logon interfaces with human users.

3.2.15.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

banner login You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided
banner login for USG-authorized use only.
banner login
banner login By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the
banner login following conditions:
banner login
banner login -The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes
banner login including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network
banner login operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and
banner login counterintelligence (CI) investigations.
banner login
banner login -At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.
banner login
banner login -Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine
banner login monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-
banner login authorized purpose.
banner login
banner login -This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect
banner login USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.
banner login
banner login -Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI
banner login investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or
banner login work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys,
banner login psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product
banner login are private and banner login confidential. See User Agreement for details.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to display the Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner before granting access to the device, this is a finding.

3.2.15.4 Findings

3.2.15.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

The Login banner message on Office-Cisco-ASA was:

Authorized use only!

3.2.15.5 Fix

ASA(config)# banner login You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided
ASA(config)# banner login for USG-authorized use only.
ASA(config)# banner login
ASA(config)# banner login By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the
ASA(config)# banner login following conditions:
ASA(config)# banner login
ASA(config)# banner login -The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes
ASA(config)# banner login including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network
ASA(config)# banner login operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and
ASA(config)# banner login counterintelligence (CI) investigations.
ASA(config)# banner login
ASA(config)# banner login -At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.
ASA(config)# banner login
ASA(config)# banner login -Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine
ASA(config)# banner login monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-
ASA(config)# banner login authorized purpose.
ASA(config)# banner login
ASA(config)# banner login -This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect
ASA(config)# banner login USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.
ASA(config)# banner login
ASA(config)# banner login -Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI
ASA(config)# banner login investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or
ASA(config)# banner login work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys,
ASA(config)# banner login psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product
ASA(config)# banner login are private and ASA(config)# banner login confidential. See User Agreement for details.
ASA(config)# end

3.2.15.6 CCI References

The information system displays an organization-defined system use notification message or banner before granting access to the system that provides privacy and security notices consistent with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-8 a;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-8.1 (ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-8 a.

3.2.15.7 Additional Information

  • Reference ID : 5342
