  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000048
  • Fix ID : F-43094r666068_fix
  • Check ID : C-43135r666067_chk

3.2.16 SRG-APP-000080-NDM-000220

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239903
  • Rule ID : SV-239903r666072_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000166
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000210
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.16.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to protect against an individual (or process acting on behalf of an individual) falsely denying having performed organization-defined actions to be covered by non-repudiation.

3.2.16.2 Discussion

This requirement supports non-repudiation of actions taken by an administrator and is required in order to maintain the integrity of the configuration management process. All configuration changes to the network device are logged. To meet this requirement, the network device must log administrator access and activity.

3.2.16.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands that include the name of the user. The ASA also logs the name of the user entering the enable command.

If logging of administrator activity is not configured, this is a finding.

3.2.16.4 Findings

3.2.16.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.16.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to log administrator activity as shown below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.16.6 CCI References

The information system protects against an individual (or process acting on behalf of an individual) falsely denying having performed organization-defined actions to be covered by non-repudiation.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-10;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-10.1;
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-10.

3.2.16.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000166
  • Fix ID : F-43095r666071_fix
  • Check ID : C-43136r666070_chk

3.2.17 SRG-APP-000091-NDM-000223

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239904
  • Rule ID : SV-239904r666075_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000172
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000240
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.17.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to generate audit records when successful/unsuccessful attempts to access privileges occur.

3.2.17.2 Discussion

Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

3.2.17.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all login attempts as well as the name of the user entering the enable command.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to generate audit records when successful/unsuccessful attempts to logon, this is a finding.

3.2.17.4 Findings

3.2.17.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.17.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.17.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records for the events defined in AU-2 d. with the content defined in AU-3.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-12 c;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-12.1 (iv);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-12 c.

3.2.17.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000172
  • Fix ID : F-43096r666074_fix
  • Check ID : C-43137r666073_chk

3.2.18 SRG-APP-000095-NDM-000225

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239905
  • Rule ID : SV-239905r666078_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000130
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000260
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.18.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to produce audit log records containing sufficient information to establish what type of event occurred.

3.2.18.2 Discussion

It is essential for security personnel to know what is being done, what was attempted, where it was done, when it was done, and by whom it was done in order to compile an accurate risk assessment. Associating event types with detected events in the application and audit logs provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured network device. Without this capability, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events leading up to an outage or attack.

3.2.18.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

If the ASA is not configured to generate audit records containing information to establish what type of event occurred, this is a finding.

3.2.18.4 Findings

3.2.18.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.18.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.18.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records containing information that establishes what type of event occurred.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-3;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-3.1;
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-3.

3.2.18.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000130
  • Fix ID : F-43097r666077_fix
  • Check ID : C-43138r666076_chk

3.2.19 SRG-APP-000096-NDM-000226

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239906
  • Rule ID : SV-239906r666081_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000131
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000270
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.19.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to produce audit records containing information to establish when (date and time) the events occurred.

3.2.19.2 Discussion

It is essential for security personnel to know what is being done, what was attempted, where it was done, when it was done, and by whom it was done in order to compile an accurate risk assessment. Logging the date and time of each detected event provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured network device. In order to establish and correlate the series of events leading up to an outage or attack, it is imperative the date and time are recorded in all log records.

3.2.19.3 Check

Verify that the ASA is configured to include the date and time on all log records as shown in the configuration example below.

logging timestamp

If time stamp is not configured, this is a finding.

3.2.19.4 Findings

3.2.19.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that Office-Cisco-ASA was configured to log messages without a timestamp.

3.2.19.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to include the date and time on all log records as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging timestamp

3.2.19.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records containing information that establishes when an event occurred.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-3;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-3.1;
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-3.

3.2.19.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000131
  • Fix ID : F-43098r666080_fix
  • Check ID : C-43139r666079_chk

3.2.20 SRG-APP-000097-NDM-000227

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239907
  • Rule ID : SV-239907r666084_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000132
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000280
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.20.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to produce audit records containing information to establish where the events occurred.

3.2.20.2 Discussion

In order to compile an accurate risk assessment and provide forensic analysis, it is essential for security personnel to know where events occurred, such as device hardware components, device software modules, session identifiers, filenames, host names, and functionality.

Associating information about where the event occurred within the network device provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured device.

3.2.20.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below.

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log location (IP address or console) from where configuration commands are entered.

If the ASA is not configured to generate audit records containing information to establish where the events occurred, this is a finding.

3.2.20.4 Findings

3.2.20.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.20.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.20.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records containing information that establishes where the event occurred.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-3;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-3.1;
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-3.

3.2.20.7 Additional Information

  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM

3.2.21 SRG-APP-000098-NDM-000228

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239908
  • Rule ID : SV-239908r666087_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000133
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000290
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.21.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to produce audit log records containing information to establish the source of events.

3.2.21.2 Discussion

In order to compile an accurate risk assessment and provide forensic analysis, it is essential for security personnel to know the source of the event. The source may be a component, module, or process within the device or an external session, administrator, or device.

Associating information about where the source of the event occurred provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured device.

3.2.21.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log location (IP address or console) from where configuration commands are entered.

If the ASA is not configured to generate audit records containing information to establish the source of events, this is a finding.

3.2.21.4 Findings

3.2.21.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.21.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.21.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records containing information that establishes the source of the event.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-3;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-3.1;
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-3.

  • Reference ID : 5342

3.2.22 SRG-APP-000099-NDM-000229

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239909
  • Rule ID : SV-239909r666090_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000134
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000300
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.22.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to produce audit records that contain information to establish the outcome of the event.

3.2.22.2 Discussion

Without information about the outcome of events, security personnel cannot make an accurate assessment as to whether an attack was successful or if changes were made to the security state of the system.

Event outcomes can include indicators of event success or failure and event-specific results (e.g., the security state of the device after the event occurred). As such, they also provide a means to measure the impact of an event and help authorized personnel to determine the appropriate response.

3.2.22.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational
 
If the ASA is not configured to generate audit records containing information to establish the outcome of the event, this is a finding.

3.2.22.4 Findings

3.2.22.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.22.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.22.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records containing information that establishes the outcome of the event.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-3;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-3.1;
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-3.

3.2.22.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000134
  • Fix ID : F-43101r666089_fix
  • Check ID : C-43142r666088_chk

3.2.23 SRG-APP-000101-NDM-000231

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239910
  • Rule ID : SV-239910r666093_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000135
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000320
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.23.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to generate audit records containing the full-text recording of privileged commands.

3.2.23.2 Discussion

Reconstruction of harmful events or forensic analysis is not possible if audit records do not contain enough information.

Organizations consider limiting the additional audit information to only that information explicitly needed for specific audit requirements. The additional information required is dependent on the type of information (i.e., sensitivity of the data and the environment within which it resides). At a minimum, the organization must audit full-text recording of privileged commands. The organization must maintain audit trails in sufficient detail to reconstruct events to determine the cause and impact of compromise.

3.2.23.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log full-text recording of privileged commands.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to generate audit records containing the full-text recording of privileged commands, this is a finding.

3.2.23.4 Findings

3.2.23.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.23.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.23.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records containing the organization-defined additional, more detailed information that is to be included in the audit records.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-3 (1);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-3 (1).1 (ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-3 (1).

3.2.23.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000135
  • Fix ID : F-43102r666092_fix
  • Check ID : C-43143r666091_chk

3.2.24 SRG-APP-000148-NDM-000346

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239912
  • Rule ID : SV-239912r666099_rule
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000450
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.24.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured with only one local account to be used as the account of last resort in the event the authentication server is unavailable.

3.2.24.2 Discussion

Authentication for administrative (privileged level) access to the device is required at all times. An account can be created on the device's local database for use when the authentication server is down or connectivity between the device and the authentication server is not operable. This account is referred to as the account of last resort since it is intended to be used as a last resort and when immediate administrative access is absolutely necessary.

The account of last resort logon credentials must be stored in a sealed envelope and kept in a safe. The safe must be periodically audited to verify the envelope remains sealed. The signature of the auditor and the date of the audit should be added to the envelope as a record. Administrators should secure the credentials and disable the root account (if possible) when not needed for system administration functions.

3.2.24.3 Check

Step 1: Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that a local account for last resort has been configured with a privilege level that will enable the administrator to troubleshoot connectivity to the authentication server.

username LAST_RESORT password $sha512$5000$tb2eaIcI/Q5Q==$ScFJI1ChS4gIjXw== pbkdf2 privilege 15

Step 2: Verify the fallback to use local account has been configured as shown in the example below.

user-identity default-domain LOCAL
aaa authentication serial console RADIUS_GROUP LOCAL
aaa authentication ssh console RADIUS_GROUP LOCAL

If the Cisco ASA is not configured with only one local account to be used as the account of last resort in the event the authentication server is unavailable, this is a finding.

3.2.24.4 Findings

3.2.24.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

[FAIL]

Table 158: Local users
User Password Privilege
admin (ENCRYPTED) 2
Tom (ENCRYPTED) 15

[FAIL]

Table 159: Authentication system order
Name Type For
LOCAL ssh
LOCAL telnet

3.2.24.5 Fix

Step 1: Configure a local account with the necessary privilege level to troubleshoot network outage and restore operations as shown in the following example.

ASA(config)# username LAST_RESORT privilege 15
ASA(config)# username LAST_RESORT password xxxxxxxxxxxxx

Step 2: Define the AAA server.

ASA(config)# aaa-server RADIUS_GROUP protocol radius 
ASA(config-aaa-server-group)# exit
ASA(config)# aaa-server RADIUS_GROUP (NDM_INTERFACE) host 10.1.48.10
ASA(config-aaa-server-host)# key xxxxxxxxx
ASA(config-aaa-server-host)# exit

Step 3: Configure the authentication to use an AAA server with the fallback to use the local account if the authentication server is not reachable as shown in the following example.

ASA(config)# aaa authentication serial console RADIUS_GROUP LOCAL
ASA(config)# aaa authentication ssh console RADIUS_GROUP LOCAL
ASA(config)# end

3.2.24.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-002111, CCI-001358
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-002111, CCI-001358
  • Fix ID : F-43104r666098_fix
  • Check ID : C-43145r666097_chk

3.2.25 SRG-APP-000156-NDM-000250

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239913
  • Rule ID : SV-239913r666102_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001941
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000470
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.25.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to implement replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to privileged accounts.

3.2.25.2 Discussion

A replay attack may enable an unauthorized user to gain access to the application. Authentication sessions between the authenticator and the application validating the user credentials must not be vulnerable to a replay attack.

An authentication process resists replay attacks if it is impractical to achieve a successful authentication by recording and replaying a previous authentication message.

Techniques used to address this include protocols using nonces (e.g., numbers generated for a specific one-time use) or challenges (e.g., TLS, WS_Security). Additional techniques include time-synchronous or challenge-response one-time authenticators.

3.2.25.3 Check

Step 1: Verify that FIPS mode is enabled as shown in the example.

fips enable

Step 2: Verify only SSH is configured to only use FIPS-compliant ciphers and that Diffie-Hellman Group 14 is used for the key exchange as shown in the example below.

ssh version 2
ssh cipher encryption fips
ssh key-exchange group dh-group14-sha1

Note: The ASA only supports SSHv2.

If the ASA is not configured to implement replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access, this is a finding.

3.2.25.4 Findings

3.2.25.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that FIPS mode was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

[FAIL]

Nipper detemined that the SSH service was configured to support versions 1 and 2 of the protocol on Office-Cisco-ASA.

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that the SSH key exchange group was set to DH Group 1 SHA1 on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.25.5 Fix

Step 1: Enable FIPS mode via the fips enable command.

Step 2: Configure SSH to only use FIPS-compliant ciphers and Diffie-Hellman Group 14 for the key exchange.

ASA(config)# ssh cipher encryption fips 
ASA(config)# ssh key-exchange group dh-group14-sha

3.2.25.6 CCI References

The information system implements replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to privileged accounts.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-2 (8).

3.2.25.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001941
  • Fix ID : F-43105r666101_fix
  • Check ID : C-43146r666100_chk

3.2.26 SRG-APP-000164-NDM-000252

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239914
  • Rule ID : SV-239914r666105_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000205
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000490
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.26.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to enforce a minimum 15-character password length.

3.2.26.2 Discussion

Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password.

The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. Use of more characters in a password helps to exponentially increase the time and/or resources required to compromise the password.

3.2.26.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

password-policy minimum-length 15

If the ASA is not configured to enforce a minimum 15-character password length, this is a finding.

3.2.26.4 Findings

3.2.26.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Forcing a minimum password length is not supported on this Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall OS version.

3.2.26.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to enforce password complexity by requiring a minimum 15-character password length as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# password-policy minimum-length 15

3.2.26.6 CCI References

The information system enforces minimum password length.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - IA-5 (1) (a);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - IA-5 (1).1 (i);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-5 (1) (a).

3.2.26.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000205
  • Fix ID : F-43106r666104_fix
  • Check ID : C-43147r666103_chk

3.2.27 SRG-APP-000166-NDM-000254

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239915
  • Rule ID : SV-239915r666108_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000192
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000520
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.27.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used.

3.2.27.2 Discussion

Use of a complex passwords helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determine how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password is, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

Multifactor authentication (MFA) is required for all administrative and user accounts on network devices, except for an account of last resort and (where applicable) a root account. Passwords should only be used when MFA using PKI is not available, and for the account of last resort and root account.

3.2.27.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

password-policy minimum-uppercase 1

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used, this is a finding.

3.2.27.4 Findings

3.2.27.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Forcing the inclusion of uppercase characters in a password is not supported on this Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall OS version.

3.2.27.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# password-policy minimum-uppercase 1

3.2.27.6 CCI References

The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of upper case characters used.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - IA-5 (1) (a);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - IA-5 (1).1 (v);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-5 (1) (a).

3.2.27.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000192
  • Fix ID : F-43107r666107_fix
  • Check ID : C-43148r666106_chk

3.2.28 SRG-APP-000167-NDM-000255

  • Vuln ID : V-239916
  • Rule ID : SV-239916r666111_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000193
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000530
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.28.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one lowercase character be used.

3.2.28.2 Discussion

Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determine how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

Multifactor authentication (MFA) is required for all administrative and user accounts on network devices, except for an account of last resort and (where applicable) a root account. Passwords should only be used when MFA using PKI is not available, and for the account of last resort and root account.

3.2.28.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

password-policy minimum-lowercase 1

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one lowercase character be used, this is a finding.

3.2.28.4 Findings

3.2.28.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Forcing the inclusion of lowercase characters in a password is not supported on this Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall OS version.

3.2.28.5 Fix

ASA(config)# password-policy minimum-lowercase 1

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - IA-5 (1) (a);

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-5 (1) (a).

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.29.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one numeric character be used.

3.2.29.2 Discussion

Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determine how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

Multifactor authentication (MFA) is required for all administrative and user accounts on network devices, except for an account of last resort and (where applicable) a root account. Passwords should only be used when MFA using PKI is not available, and for the account of last resort and root account.

3.2.29.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

password-policy minimum-numeric 1

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one numeric character be used, this is a finding.

3.2.29.4 Findings

3.2.29.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Forcing the inclusion of numerical characters in a password is not supported on this Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall OS version.

3.2.29.5 Fix

ASA(config)# password-policy minimum-numeric 1

3.2.30 SRG-APP-000169-NDM-000257

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239918
  • Rule ID : SV-239918r666117_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001619
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000570
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.30.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one special character be used.

3.2.30.2 Discussion

Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determine how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

Multifactor authentication (MFA) is required for all administrative and user accounts on network devices, except for an account of last resort and (where applicable) a root account. Passwords should only be used when MFA using PKI is not available, and for the account of last resort and root account.

3.2.30.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

password-policy minimum-special 1

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one special character be used, this is a finding.

3.2.30.4 Findings

3.2.30.5 Fix

ASA(config)# password-policy minimum-special 1

3.2.31 SRG-APP-000170-NDM-000329

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239919
  • Rule ID : SV-239919r666120_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000195
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000580
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.31.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to require that when a password is changed, the characters are changed in at least eight of the positions within the password.

3.2.31.2 Discussion

If the application allows the user to consecutively reuse extensive portions of passwords, this increases the chances of password compromise by increasing the window of opportunity for attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

The number of changed characters refers to the number of changes required with respect to the total number of positions in the current password. In other words, characters may be the same within the two passwords; however, the positions of the like characters must be different.

Multifactor authentication (MFA) is required for all administrative and user accounts on network devices, except for an account of last resort and (where applicable) a root account. Passwords should only be used when MFA using PKI is not available, and for the account of last resort and root account.

3.2.31.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration to verify it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

password-policy minimum-changes 8

If the Cisco router is not configured to require that when a password is changed, the characters are changed in at least eight of the positions within the password, this is a finding.

3.2.31.4 Findings

3.2.31.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Forcing a minumum number of character changes in a password is not supported on this Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall OS version.

3.2.31.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to enforce password complexity by requiring that when a password is changed, the characters are changed in at least eight of the positions within the password as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# password-policy minimum-changes 8

3.2.31.6 CCI References

The information system, for password-based authentication, when new passwords are created, enforces that at least an organization-defined number of characters are changed.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - IA-5 (1) (b);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - IA-5 (1).1 (v);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-5 (1) (b).

3.2.31.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000195
  • Fix ID : F-43111r666119_fix
  • Check ID : C-43152r666118_chk

3.2.32 SRG-APP-000343-NDM-000289

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239921
  • Rule ID : SV-239921r666126_rule
  • CCI : CCI-002234
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000910
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.32.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to audit the execution of privileged functions.

3.2.32.2 Discussion

Misuse of privileged functions, either intentionally or unintentionally by authorized users, or by unauthorized external entities that have compromised information system accounts, is a serious and ongoing concern and can have significant adverse impacts on organizations. Auditing the use of privileged functions is one way to detect such misuse and identify the risk from insider threats and the advanced persistent threat.

3.2.32.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration example below will log all configuration changes.

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to log all configuration changes, this is a finding.

3.2.32.4 Findings

3.2.32.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.32.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to log all configuration changes as shown in the following example.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.32.6 CCI References

The information system audits the execution of privileged functions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-6 (9).

3.2.32.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-002234
  • Fix ID : F-43113r666125_fix
  • Check ID : C-43154r666124_chk

3.2.33 SRG-APP-000357-NDM-000293

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239922
  • Rule ID : SV-239922r666129_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001849
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000920
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Pass)

3.2.33.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to allocate audit record storage capacity in accordance with organization-defined audit record storage requirements.

3.2.33.2 Discussion

In order to ensure network devices have a sufficient storage capacity in which to write the audit logs, they need to be able to allocate audit record storage capacity. The task of allocating audit record storage capacity is usually performed during initial device setup if it is modifiable.

The value for the organization-defined audit record storage requirement will depend on the amount of storage available on the network device, the anticipated volume of logs, the frequency of transfer from the network device to centralized log servers, and other factors.

3.2.33.3 Check

Verify the Cisco ASA is configured with a logfile size. The configuration should look like the example below.

logging flash-bufferwrap
logging flash-minimum-free nnnnnnn
logging flash-maximum-allocation nnnnnnn

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to allocate audit record storage capacity in accordance with organization-defined audit record storage requirements, this is a finding.

3.2.33.4 Findings

3.2.33.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

[PASS]

Nipper determined that when logging messages to the flash storage, Office-Cisco-ASA was configured with a maximum logging size of 1.00 MiB.

[PASS]

Nipper determined that when logging messages to the flash storage, Office-Cisco-ASA was configured to leave at least 3.00 MiB of free space.

3.2.33.5 Fix

Configure the buffer size for logging as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging flash-maximum-allocation nnnnnnn
ASA(config)# logging flash-minimum-free nnnnnnn

3.2.33.6 CCI References

The organization allocates audit record storage capacity in accordance with organization-defined audit record storage requirements.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-4.

3.2.33.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001849
  • Fix ID : F-43114r666128_fix
  • Check ID : C-43155r666127_chk

3.2.34 SRG-APP-000360-NDM-000295

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239923
  • Rule ID : SV-239923r666132_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001858
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000930
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Pass)

3.2.34.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to generate an immediate real-time alert of all audit failure events requiring real-time alerts.

3.2.34.2 Discussion

It is critical for the appropriate personnel to be aware if a system is at risk of failing to process audit logs as required. Without a real-time alert, security personnel may be unaware of an impending failure of the audit capability and system operation may be adversely affected.

Alerts provide organizations with urgent messages. Real-time alerts provide these messages immediately (i.e., the time from event detection to alert occurs in seconds or less).

3.2.34.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

logging trap critical
logging host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10

Note: The parameter critical can replaced with a lesser severity (i.e., error, warning, notice, informational). A logging list can be used as an alternative to the severity level.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to generate an alert for all audit failure events, this is a finding.

3.2.34.4 Findings

3.2.34.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that logging to a Syslog server was enabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Table 160: Syslog hosts
Host Protocol Port Secure
10.100.1.1 UDP 514 No

3.2.34.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to send critical to emergency log messages to the syslog server as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10
ASA(config)# logging trap critical
ASA(config)# end

Note: The parameter critical can replaced with a lesser severity (i.e., error, warning, notice, informational).

3.2.34.6 CCI References

The information system provides a real-time alert in an organization-defined real-time period to organization-defined personnel, roles, and/or locations when organization-defined audit failure events requiring real-time alerts occur.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-5 (2).

3.2.34.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001858
  • Fix ID : F-43115r666131_fix
  • Check ID : C-43156r666130_chk

3.2.35 SRG-APP-000373-NDM-000298

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239924
  • Rule ID : SV-239924r666135_rule
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000940
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Pass)

3.2.35.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to synchronize its clock with the primary and secondary time sources using redundant authoritative time sources.

3.2.35.2 Discussion

The loss of connectivity to a particular authoritative time source will result in the loss of time synchronization (free-run mode) and increasingly inaccurate time stamps on audit events and other functions.

Multiple time sources provide redundancy by including a secondary source. Time synchronization is usually a hierarchy; clients synchronize time to a local source while that source synchronizes its time to a more accurate source. The network device must utilize an authoritative time server and/or be configured to use redundant authoritative time sources. This requirement is related to the comparison done in CCI-001891.

DoD-approved solutions consist of a combination of a primary and secondary time source using a combination or multiple instances of the following: a time server designated for the appropriate DoD network (NIPRNet/SIPRNet); United States Naval Observatory (USNO) time servers; and/or the Global Positioning System (GPS). The secondary time source must be located in a different geographic region than the primary time source.

3.2.35.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the configuration example below.

ntp server 10.1.22.2
ntp server 10.1.48.8 prefer

Note: For ASAs running on Firepower Chassis hardware, the NTP settings are visible in the FXOS web UI only (not in the ASA CLI or ASDM web UI).

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to synchronize its clock with redundant authoritative time sources, this is a finding.

3.2.35.4 Findings

3.2.35.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA
Table 161: NTP client time sources
Address Auth Key Interface
192.168.2.2    
192.168.80.254    

3.2.35.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to synchronize its clock with redundant authoritative time sources as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# ntp server 10.1.48.8 prefer
ASA(config)# ntp server 10.1.22.2
ASA(config)# end

3.2.35.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001893, CCI-000366
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001893, CCI-000366
  • Fix ID : F-43116r666134_fix
  • Check ID : C-43157r666133_chk

3.2.36 SRG-APP-000375-NDM-000300

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239925
  • Rule ID : SV-239925r666138_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001889
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000970
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.36.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to record time stamps for audit records that meet a granularity of one second for a minimum degree of precision.

3.2.36.2 Discussion

Without sufficient granularity of time stamps, it is not possible to adequately determine the chronological order of records. Time stamps generated by the application include date and time. Granularity of time measurements refers to the degree of synchronization between information system clocks and reference clocks.

3.2.36.3 Check

Verify the ASA is configured to include the time on all log records as shown in the configuration example below.

logging timestamp

If time stamp is not configured, this is a finding.

3.2.36.4 Findings

3.2.36.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that Office-Cisco-ASA was configured to log messages without a timestamp.

3.2.36.5 Fix

Configure the ASA to include the time on all log records as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging timestamp

3.2.36.6 CCI References

The information system records time stamps for audit records that meet organization-defined granularity of time measurement.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-8 b.

3.2.36.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001889
  • Fix ID : F-43117r666137_fix
  • Check ID : C-43158r666136_chk

3.2.37 SRG-APP-000374-NDM-000299

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239926
  • Rule ID : SV-239926r666141_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001890
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-000980
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Pass)

3.2.37.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to record time stamps for audit records that can be mapped to Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) or Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).

3.2.37.2 Discussion

If time stamps are not consistently applied and there is no common time reference, it is difficult to perform forensic analysis.

Time stamps generated by the application include date and time. Time is commonly expressed in UTC, a modern continuation of GMT, or local time with an offset from UTC.

3.2.37.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

clock timezone EST -5 0

Note: UTC is the default; hence, the command set time-zone may not be seen in the configuration. This can be verified using the show clock command. For ASAs running on Firepower Chassis hardware, the NTP settings are visible in the FXOS web UI only (not in the ASA CLI or ASDM web UI).

If the configuration is not compliant, this is a finding.

3.2.37.4 Findings

3.2.37.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that the timezone was set to UTC on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.37.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to record time stamps for audit records that can be mapped to UTC or GMT as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# clock timezone EST -5 0

3.2.37.6 CCI References

The information system records time stamps for audit records that can be mapped to Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) or Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-8 b.

3.2.37.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001890
  • Fix ID : F-43118r666140_fix
  • Check ID : C-43159r666139_chk

3.2.38 SRG-APP-000395-NDM-000310

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239927
  • Rule ID : SV-239927r666144_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001967
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001050
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.38.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to authenticate Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) messages using a FIPS-validated Keyed-Hash Message Authentication Code (HMAC).

3.2.38.2 Discussion

Without authenticating devices, unidentified or unknown devices may be introduced, thereby facilitating malicious activity. Bidirectional authentication provides stronger safeguards to validate the identity of other devices for connections that are of greater risk.

A local connection is any connection with a device communicating without the use of a network. A network connection is any connection with a device that communicates through a network (e.g., local area or wide area network, internet). A remote connection is any connection with a device communicating through an external network (e.g., the internet).

Because of the challenges of applying this requirement on a large scale, organizations are encouraged to only apply the requirement to those limited number (and type) of devices that truly need to support this capability.

3.2.38.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

snmp-server group NETOPS v3 priv
snmp-server user FWADMIN NETOPS v3 engineID xxxxxxxxxxxx encrypted auth sha xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
snmp-server host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10 version 3 FWADMIN

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to authenticate SNMP messages using a FIPS-validated HMAC, this is a finding.

3.2.38.4 Findings

3.2.38.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper identified two SNMP community strings on Office-Cisco-ASA. Those SNMP community string are described in the following table:

Table 162: SNMP Community Strings
Community Access Version
(HIDDEN) Read Only 1
(HIDDEN) Read Only 2c
Table 163: SNMP NMS Hosts
Community Interface Host
(HIDDEN) OfficeOUTSIDE 192.168.20.30
  OfficeVLAN1 10.10.20.20
(HIDDEN) OfficeOUTSIDE 10.20.45.39

Nipper identified the following SNMP user on Office-Cisco-ASA that was not configured with FIPS 140-2 compliant authentication hashing.

Table 164: Non FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP user authentication
User Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password
Charles 3 Auth+Priv MD5 (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)

Nipper identified the following two SNMP users on Office-Cisco-ASA that were configured to use a FIPS 140-2 compliant privacy encryption algorithm.

Table 165: FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP user privacy
User Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password
Tom 3 Auth+Priv SHA (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)
Charles 3 Auth+Priv MD5 (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)
Table 166: Non FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP trap/inform hosts
Host Version Community Port Interface
1.1.1.1 1 (HIDDEN) 162 OfficeOUTSIDE

3.2.38.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to authenticate SNMP messages as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# snmp-server group NETOPS v3 priv
ASA(config)# snmp-server user FWADMIN NETOPS v3 auth sha xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
ASA(config)# snmp-server host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10 version 3 FWADMIN
ASA(config)# end

3.2.38.6 CCI References

The information system authenticates organization-defined devices and/or types of devices before establishing a local, remote, and/or network connection using bidirectional authentication that is cryptographically based.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-3 (1).

3.2.38.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001967
  • Fix ID : F-43119r666143_fix
  • Check ID : C-43160r666142_chk

3.2.39 SRG-APP-000395-NDM-000310

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239928
  • Rule ID : SV-239928r666147_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001967
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001070
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.39.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to encrypt Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) messages using a FIPS 140-2 approved algorithm.

3.2.39.2 Discussion

Without authenticating devices, unidentified or unknown devices may be introduced, thereby facilitating malicious activity. Bidirectional authentication provides stronger safeguards to validate the identity of other devices for connections that are of greater risk.

A local connection is any connection with a device communicating without the use of a network. A network connection is any connection with a device that communicates through a network (e.g., local area or wide area network, internet). A remote connection is any connection with a device communicating through an external network (e.g., the internet).

Because of the challenges of applying this requirement on a large scale, organizations are encouraged to only apply the requirement to those limited number (and type) of devices that truly need to support this capability.

3.2.39.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

snmp-server group NETOPS v3 priv
snmp-server user FWADMIN NETOPS v3 engineID xxxxxxxxxxxx encrypted auth sha xxxxxxxxxxxx priv aes xxxxxxxxxxxx
snmp-server host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10 version 3 FWADMIN

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to encrypt SNMP messages using a FIPS 140-2 approved algorithm, this is a finding.

3.2.39.4 Findings

3.2.39.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper identified two SNMP community strings on Office-Cisco-ASA. Those SNMP community string are described in the following table:

Table 167: SNMP Community Strings
Community Access Version
(HIDDEN) Read Only 1
(HIDDEN) Read Only 2c
Table 168: SNMP NMS Hosts
Community Interface Host
(HIDDEN) OfficeOUTSIDE 192.168.20.30
  OfficeVLAN1 10.10.20.20
(HIDDEN) OfficeOUTSIDE 10.20.45.39

Nipper identified the following SNMP user on Office-Cisco-ASA that was not configured with FIPS 140-2 compliant authentication hashing.

Table 169: Non FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP user authentication
User Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password
Charles 3 Auth+Priv MD5 (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)

Nipper identified the following two SNMP users on Office-Cisco-ASA that were configured to use a FIPS 140-2 compliant privacy encryption algorithm.

Table 170: FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP user privacy
User Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password
Tom 3 Auth+Priv SHA (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)
Charles 3 Auth+Priv MD5 (ENCRYPTED) AES-256 (ENCRYPTED)
Table 171: Non FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP trap/inform hosts
Host Version Community Port Interface
1.1.1.1 1 (HIDDEN) 162 OfficeOUTSIDE

3.2.39.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to encrypt SNMP messages using a FIPS 140-2 approved algorithm as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# snmp-server group NETOPS v3 priv
ASA(config)# snmp-server user FWADMIN NETOPS v3 auth sha xxxxxxxxxx priv aes xxxxxxxxxx
ASA(config)# snmp-server host NDM_INTERFACE 10.1.48.10 version 3 FWADMIN
ASA(config)# end

3.2.39.6 CCI References

The information system authenticates organization-defined devices and/or types of devices before establishing a local, remote, and/or network connection using bidirectional authentication that is cryptographically based.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-3 (1).

3.2.39.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001967
  • Fix ID : F-43120r666146_fix
  • Check ID : C-43161r666145_chk

3.2.40 SRG-APP-000395-NDM-000347

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239929
  • Rule ID : SV-239929r666150_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001967
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001080
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.40.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to authenticate Network Time Protocol sources using authentication that is cryptographically based.

3.2.40.2 Discussion

If Network Time Protocol is not authenticated, an attacker can introduce a rogue NTP server. This rogue server can then be used to send incorrect time information to network devices, which will make log timestamps inaccurate and affect scheduled actions. NTP authentication is used to prevent this tampering by authenticating the time source.

3.2.40.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the configuration example below.

ntp authentication-key 1 md5 *****
ntp authenticate
ntp trusted-key 1
ntp server 10.1.12.2 key 1 prefer
ntp server 10.1.48.10 key 1

Note: For ASAs running on Firepower Chassis hardware, the NTP settings are visible in the FXOS web UI only (not in the ASA CLI or ASDM web UI).

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to authenticate NTP sources using authentication that is cryptographically based, this is a finding.

3.2.40.4 Findings

3.2.40.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA
Table 172: NTP client time sources
Address Auth Key Interface
192.168.2.2    
192.168.80.254    

3.2.40.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to authenticate NTP sources using authentication that is cryptographically based as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# ntp authenticate
ASA(config)# ntp authentication-key 1 md5 xxxxxxxxxx
ASA(config)# ntp trusted-key 1
ASA(config)# ntp server 10.1.12.2 key 1 prefer
ASA(config)# ntp server 10.1.48.10 key 1
ASA(config)# end

3.2.40.6 CCI References

The information system authenticates organization-defined devices and/or types of devices before establishing a local, remote, and/or network connection using bidirectional authentication that is cryptographically based.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-3 (1).

3.2.40.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001967
  • Fix ID : F-43121r666149_fix
  • Check ID : C-43162r666148_chk

3.2.41 SRG-APP-000435-NDM-000315

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239932
  • Rule ID : SV-239932r666159_rule
  • CCI : CCI-002385
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001180
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Pass)

3.2.41.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to protect against known types of Denial of Service (DoS) attacks by enabling the
Threat Detection feature.

3.2.41.2 Discussion

DoS is a condition when a resource is not available for legitimate users. When this occurs, the organization either cannot accomplish its mission or must operate at degraded capacity.

This requirement addresses the configuration of network devices to mitigate the impact of DoS attacks that have occurred or are ongoing on device availability. For each network device, known and potential DoS attacks must be identified and solutions for each type implemented. A variety of technologies exist to limit or, in some cases, eliminate the effects of DoS attacks (e.g., limiting processes or restricting the number of sessions the device opens at one time). Employing increased capacity and bandwidth, combined with service redundancy, may reduce the susceptibility to some DoS attacks.

The security safeguards cannot be defined at the DoD level because they vary according to the capabilities of the individual network devices and the security controls applied on the adjacent networks (for example, firewalls performing packet filtering to block DoS attacks).

3.2.41.3 Check

Review the ASA configuration and verify the Threat Detection feature is enabled as shown in the example below.

threat-detection basic-threat

If the Cisco ASA does not have the Threat Detection feature enabled, this is a finding.

3.2.41.4 Findings

3.2.41.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA
Table 173: Threat detection configuration
Feature Description State
Basic Threats Detection and protection of basic threats, which includes DoS attacks, bad and malformed packets, connection limits, scan detection, interface overload and basic firewall checks. Protect

3.2.41.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to protect against known types of DoS attacks by enabling the Threat Detection feature.

ASA(config)# threat-detection basic-threat
ASA(config)# end

3.2.41.6 CCI References

The information system protects against or limits the effects of organization-defined types of denial of service attacks by employing organization-defined security safeguards.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - SC-5.

3.2.41.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-002385
  • Fix ID : F-43124r666158_fix
  • Check ID : C-43165r666157_chk

3.2.42 SRG-APP-000495-NDM-000318

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239933
  • Rule ID : SV-239933r666162_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000172
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001200
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.42.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to generate audit records when successful/unsuccessful attempts to modify administrator privileges occur.

3.2.42.2 Discussion

Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

Audit records can be generated from various components within the network device (e.g., module or policy filter).

3.2.42.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below.

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to generate log records when administrator privileges are modified, this is a finding.

3.2.42.4 Findings

3.2.42.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.42.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA to generate log records when account privileges are modified as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.42.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records for the events defined in AU-2 d. with the content defined in AU-3.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-12 c;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-12.1 (iv);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-12 c.

3.2.42.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 5342
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco ASA NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco ASA NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000172
  • Fix ID : F-43125r666161_fix
  • Check ID : C-43166r666160_chk

3.2.43 SRG-APP-000499-NDM-000319

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239934
  • Rule ID : SV-239934r666165_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000172
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001210
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.43.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to generate audit records when successful/unsuccessful attempts to delete administrator privileges occur.

3.2.43.2 Discussion

Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

Audit records can be generated from various components within the network device (e.g., module or policy filter).

3.2.43.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below.

logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to generate log records when administrator privileges are deleted, this is a finding.

3.2.43.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

ASA(config)# logging buffered informational

3.2.44 SRG-APP-000503-NDM-000320

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239935
  • Rule ID : SV-239935r666168_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000172
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001220
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.44.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to generate audit records when successful/unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

3.2.44.2 Discussion

Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

Audit records can be generated from various components within the network device (e.g., module or policy filter).

3.2.44.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below.

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all login attempts.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to generate audit records when successful/unsuccessful attempts to logon, this is a finding.

3.2.44.4 Findings

3.2.44.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.44.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco ASA as shown in the example below.

ASA(config)# logging enable
ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end

3.2.44.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records for the events defined in AU-2 d. with the content defined in AU-3.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-12 c;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-12.1 (iv);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-12 c.

3.2.45 SRG-APP-000504-NDM-000321

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-239936
  • Rule ID : SV-239936r666171_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000172
  • STIG ID : CASA-ND-001230
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Firewall Office-Cisco-ASA (Fail)

3.2.45.1 Summary

The Cisco ASA must be configured to generate audit records for privileged activities or other system-level access.

3.2.45.2 Discussion

Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

Audit records can be generated from various components within the network device (e.g., module or policy filter).

3.2.45.3 Check

Review the Cisco ASA configuration to verify it is compliant with this requirement. The configuration should look similar to the example below.

logging enable
logging buffered informational

Note: The ASA will log all EXEC-mode commands.

If the Cisco ASA is not configured to generate log records for privileged activities, this is a finding.

3.2.45.4 Findings

3.2.45.4.1 Office-Cisco-ASA

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

Nipper determined that buffered logging was disabled on Office-Cisco-ASA.

3.2.45.5 Fix

ASA(config)# logging buffered informational
ASA(config)# end
